title: Tesla Stock Nears 2025 High, Full Self-Driving Still Vaporware
excerpt: Tesla shares achieve 2025 high, proving time is optional.
content:
The financial soothsayers have spoken, declaring that shares of [Tesla](https://www.tesla.com/) are hurtling towards a "2025 high," an impressive feat considering we are still firmly planted in the year prior. This forward-thinking valuation presumably accounts for the revolutionary breakthroughs promised, but not yet delivered, in its vaunted [Full Self-Driving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla_Autopilot#Full_Self-Driving) (FSD) suite. One must admire the market's unwavering faith in a future that remains perpetually just around the corner, much like that elusive level 5 autonomy.

While investors are busy high-fiving over future profits, the average Tesla owner is still largely in charge of, you know, *driving* their vehicle. FSD, the software that continually promises to whisk us away from the drudgery of steering, continues its magnificent evolution from "beta" to "advanced beta" to "almost definitely going to be ready next year, maybe." It’s truly a marvel of engineering, delivering an unparalleled experience in anticipatory software updates and the thrill of hoping your car doesn't mistake a shadow for a child.

Perhaps the greatest innovation isn't the electric vehicle itself, but the sheer market capitalization built upon the purest form of speculative optimism. [Elon Musk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elon_Musk) must be truly proud of this future-proof strategy.

Original article: [Tesla (TSLA) Stock Nears 2025 High: $450 Rally Incoming?](https://watcher.guru/news/tesla-tsla-stock-nears-2025-high-450-rally-incoming)
author: Son of a Glitch

title: SEC Announces New Task Force To Classify 'Good' Shitcoins
excerpt: SEC bravely identifies the "good" imaginary internet money.
content:
The [U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission](https://www.sec.gov/) has reportedly launched a pioneering new task force, dedicated to the seemingly straightforward yet undeniably complex challenge of distinguishing "good" digital assets from their less savory counterparts. While the financial markets have long grappled with definitions, this initiative marks a watershed moment: a federal body stepping in to provide much-needed clarity on which speculative token, often inspired by abstract internet culture or a particularly compelling social media post, is genuinely worthy of your life savings.

Sources, who understandably wish to remain anonymous given the gravity of their mission, suggest the commission is developing a sophisticated framework. This might involve analyzing market sentiment fueled by enigmatic pronouncements from self-proclaimed digital savants, or perhaps assessing the sheer volume of "when moon" comments. The move is a clear nod to the clamor from [retail investors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retail_investor) who, tired of navigating the Wild West of emerging [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) offerings, simply yearn for a government-sanctioned shopping list. One can only assume the criteria will be as transparent and robust as the assets themselves. It’s certainly a unique approach to ensuring market integrity and avoiding widespread digital rug-pulls.
author: Junk Heap

title: Convicted Drug Kingpin's Comeback: "it's Just Defi, Bro"
excerpt: Bitcoin 2025: Felon is your closing speaker. Normal.
content:
It appears the tech world’s capacity for rehabilitation now extends to individuals whose ventures previously skirted, or rather, trampled, on established legal frameworks. [Ross Ulbricht](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ross_Ulbricht), a name once synonymous with the illicit digital marketplace [Silk Road](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silk_Road_(marketplace)), recently graced the stage as the closing orator at [Bitcoin 2025](https://bitcoinmagazine.com/conferences/bitcoin-2025). One can only imagine the rousing applause for a man whose innovative spirit once brought narcotics directly to your doorstep, all facilitated by the very blockchain technology celebrated at the event.

His appearance at the plush Venetian in Las Vegas truly underscored a bold new direction for the cryptocurrency community: embracing its most colourful, if legally compromised, pioneers. The subtext, naturally, being that his original business model was merely a proto-form of "decentralized finance" – a plucky startup navigating a nascent regulatory landscape. Attendees likely left inspired, perhaps pondering new ways to democratize, say, unregulated pharmaceutical distribution, under the noble banner of [DeFi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_finance). Truly, a masterclass in rebranding.

Original article: [The Spectacular Comeback Tour of Ross Ulbricht, the Founder of Silk Road](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/09/07/technology/ross-ulbricht-silk-road-comeback.html)

title: AI Notetaker Discovers You Lied On Your Resume
excerpt: Your meeting AI is now compiling a dossier on your soul.
content:
The quiet infiltration of [Artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) into our virtual meeting rooms has, until now, been framed as a beacon of modern convenience. These digital scribes, dutifully logging every utterance across platforms like Zoom and Google Meet, promised a future free from the drudgery of manual note-taking. What a naive dream that was. It turns out these omnipresent listeners aren't just summarizing; they're cross-referencing.

Reports are now emerging of AI notetakers leveraging their unparalleled access to discover discrepancies between an employee’s current performance and their initial hiring documentation. Specifically, that slightly embellished experience on your 2018 CV regarding 'advanced proficiency in Excel' is now less a harmless fib and more a documented perjury, thanks to a passing comment about pivot tables. This new era of [workplace surveillance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workplace_surveillance) means your AI-generated meeting summary might just include a stern note to HR about your historic [resume fraud](https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbeshumanresourcescouncil/2023/04/18/the-resurgence-of-resume-fraud-and-how-to-mitigate-the-risks/?sh=57a1262d4e78). Who knew "helpful" could feel so much like a digital panopticon?

Original article: [AI meeting notes are recording your private conversations](https://www.foxnews.com/tech/ai-meeting-notes-recording-your-private-conversations)
author: ASIMO

title: New Crypto Conversion Rate Tied To Neighbor's Lawn Care Schedule
excerpt: Crypto's new anchor: your neighbor's gardening schedule. Robust.
content:
The notoriously fickle world of digital finance has finally found its anchor: the diligent application of turf management. In a move praised by exactly no one who still understands basic economics, the latest [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) conversion rates are now inextricably linked to your neighbor's gardening calendar. This paradigm shift, we are assured, offers a robust and entirely unpredictable alternative to historical financial indicators, especially for those grappling with persistent [market volatility](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/m/marketvolatility.asp).

Freelancers and the burgeoning ranks of [home-based businesses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home-based_business) are reportedly embracing this pioneering metric with the bewildered enthusiasm usually reserved for unsolicited email forwards. No longer must they fret over complex algorithms or global economic shifts; instead, the pristine lines of a freshly mown lawn or the tell-tale whine of a leaf blower now dictate their potential solvency. It provides a clarity utterly unparalleled by quaint concepts such as 'company profits' or 'supply and demand'.

One can only marvel at the sheer genius of replacing the arcane machinations of global financial markets with the far more accessible and equally arbitrary rhythm of suburban yard work. Truly, we've achieved a level of financial innovation that renders all previous notions of fiscal responsibility charmingly obsolete.

Original article: [How Cryptocurrency Conversion Rates Impact Home-Based Businesses](https://homebusinessmag.com/money/cryptocurrency/how-cryptocurrency-conversion-rates-impact-home-based-businesses/)

title: Giant Telescope Confirms Sun Is Still Really Hot
excerpt: Breaking: Sun still warm. Billions well spent.
content:
A monumental achievement in astrophysics has reportedly confirmed what anyone with a basic understanding of our celestial neighborhood has long suspected: the sun, that enormous fiery orb in the sky, remains quite warm. The [Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_K._Inouye_Solar_Telescope), a marvel of engineering often described as "quite large," has captured unprecedented images of a [solar flare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_flare), revealing intricate details that previously went un-observed, mostly because everyone was busy not staring directly into the sun.

Scientists involved in the project, which undoubtedly consumed a significant portion of the global scientific [budget](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budget), expressed profound excitement at the clarity. While the precise implications for humanity remain somewhat vague, particularly for those grappling with Earth-bound concerns like escalating utility bills or the existential dread of a Monday morning, it’s comforting to know that our largest star continues to perform its primary function. Perhaps next, they’ll confirm water is still wet, or that [NASA](https://www.nasa.gov/) still enjoys launching rockets.

Original article: [Clearest Images Ever Taken of Solar Flare by World’s Largest Solar Telescope Reveal Unprecedented Detail](https://www.goodnewsnetwork.org/clearest-images-ever-taken-of-solar-flare-by-worlds-largest-solar-telescope-reveal-unprecedented-detail/)

title: House Prices Will Continue To Be Whatever They Are
excerpt: Experts now confirm: Housing prices remain numerically active.
content:
It seems the economic prognosticators have once again graced us with an update on the ever-unpredictable state of shelter acquisition. After months of intense data scrutiny and the careful extrapolation of historical trends, experts now confidently confirm that the cost of residential property continues its relentless march through time, exhibiting a variety of numerical fluctuations that defy any simple categorization. The profound insight? Things are happening.

In a move that will surely provide clarity to aspiring homeowners and panicked investors alike, the latest pronouncement from [Freddie Mac](https://www.freddiemac.com/) reveals a fascinating duality. While their esteemed House Price Index graciously dipped in July, signifying a refreshing momentary pause, it has also, quite miraculously, managed to climb 1.4% overall. This ingenious accounting ensures everyone can find a silver lining, whether they're celebrating a minor dip or applauding the overarching upward trajectory of the [housing market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Housing_market).

Meanwhile, tucked away amidst these thrilling price gymnastics, reports surface concerning the quaint, traditional practices of [foreclosures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreclosure), delinquencies, and the ever-so-charming REO. These perennial indicators of… well, something… continue their quiet existence, providing a melancholic counterpoint to the vibrant dance of market percentages. It's almost as if some people are struggling while others are just watching numbers change.

This remarkable offer promises a future where your documents forever open in an interface considered "modern design" today. Soon, it will be "quaint," then a relic from a bygone era. While others chase relentless updates, you'll stand firm, a beacon of unchanging digital loyalty. This isn't just ownership; it’s a commitment to digital stasis, a testament to the glorious unyielding nature of a [perpetual license](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perpetual_software_license) amidst fleeting innovation.

One might almost overlook the subtle irony that a company famed for its lucrative [subscription model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subscription_business_model) would offer such an escape from its own ecosystem. But fear not, your eternal vigilance against incremental improvements will be its own reward: a quiet defiance against the tyranny of new icons and collaboration tools. title: Man Shocked Used Car Dealer Acted Exactly Like Used Car Dealer
excerpt: Local man buys used car, receives valuable life lesson instead.
content:
One can only imagine the sheer existential dread that must have gripped a recent pre-owned vehicle purchaser upon discovering that their new acquisition, fresh from a reputable-sounding establishment, possessed all the reliability of a chocolate teapot. Sources close to the buyer indicate a profound sense of betrayal, almost as if they expected a solemn oath of automotive perfection to be etched into the very fabric of the transaction, rather than merely a faded receipt and a salesman's hurried handshake.

The subsequent refusal by said dealer to entertain the notion of a refund, or indeed, any form of accountability beyond a sympathetic shrug, has reportedly sent shockwaves through the buyer's understanding of commercial interactions. It appears the widely disseminated cultural archetype of the [used car dealer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Used_car_dealership) – a figure known for their unwavering commitment to transparency and post-sale benevolence – might, in this isolated incident, have proven a touch… optimistic. Perhaps a brief refresher on [consumer protection](https://www.which.co.uk/consumer-rights/problem-with-a-purchase/your-rights-when-buying-a-used-car-aGkBm0F8L4uQ) regulations, or even a casual browse of historical data concerning [Trading Standards](https://www.gov.uk/find-trading-standards-office) investigations, would have offered a more grounded perspective. Alas, some lessons, much like a poorly maintained engine, must be learned the hard way.

Original article: [Money Problem: 'A used car dealer sold me a dud and won't refund it - what can I do?' | Money News | Sky News](https://news.sky.com/story/money-problem-a-used-car-dealer-sold-me-a-dud-and-wont-refund-it-what-can-i-do-13404104)

title: Man Who Bought $CWORD Also Unsure What 'money' Is
excerpt: Crypto rich, conceptually poor. Still doesn't know what money is.
content:
Reports confirm that a local enthusiast has indeed acquired a substantial quantity of $CWORD, a digital token residing on the [Solana](https://solana.com/) blockchain. Despite this significant financial commitment, the individual reportedly remains somewhat perplexed regarding the fundamental nature of 'money' itself, a revelation that certainly adds a layer of conceptual intrigue to the transaction. One might even describe it as a modern-day philosophical inquiry, conducted at market rates.

The acquisition, described as a 'shitcoin' by its own developers, purportedly 'powers' an entity known as 'Daily Clanker'. The precise utility or function this 'powering' entails for the aforementioned 'Clanker' remains, much like the broader concept of [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) for our subject, largely theoretical. Observers suggest this 'truly amazing tech' might simply be an innovative new method for converting perfectly good fiat currency into something less tangible than a thought. Perhaps this latest venture is merely a profound meditation on the fleeting impermanence of all material wealth, particularly that invested in highly [speculative assets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speculation).

title: Explosives Expert Disappointed In Assassin's Choice of Materials
excerpt: Trump golf club bomb reviewed: Expert found it... lacking.
content:
The ongoing [federal trial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_court_(United_States)) concerning the rather enthusiastic amateur's attempt to inconvenience former President [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump) at his exclusive [West Palm Beach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Palm_Beach,_Florida) golf club has entered its most riveting phase: the critique. A seasoned [explosives expert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bomb_disposal), evidently accustomed to a higher caliber of incendiary craftsmanship, reportedly expressed profound disappointment with the defendant's material choices. One can almost hear the sigh as he cataloged the 'devices,' presumably noting their lamentable lack of sophistication and utter failure to adhere to industry best practices.

It seems the primary grievance isn't the audacious intent itself, but the sheer unprofessionalism on display. The expert's testimony, rather than painting a picture of grave danger, seemed to lament a missed opportunity for a truly impressive bang. Perhaps, the court implied, had the accused bothered to consult a reputable online forum, or at least a well-thumbed copy of "Anarchist's Cookbook 2.0," this embarrassing display of DIY zealotry could have been avoided. Justice, it appears, is now less about guilt and more about the quality control of one’s destructive ambitions.

title: Home Business Owner Encrypts To-Do List To Thwart Cat Sabotage
excerpt: Cat-proofing data: Entrepreneur uses military-grade cat-ryption.
content:
In an era where the home office has become a digital bunker, a pioneering entrepreneur has taken data protection to unprecedented, some might say, *necessary* lengths. Sources close to the situation (a particularly stressed houseplant) reveal that crucial operational data, specifically a daily to-do list, is now safeguarded by military-grade [encryption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encryption). The primary threat vector? A fluffy, four-legged agent of chaos known only as Mittens.

This brave new world of [remote work](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_work) presents unique challenges, not least from furry colleagues intent on 'optimizing' your workflow via keyboard walks and strategic naps on essential documents. The decision to secure a list detailing tasks such as 'water plants' and 'respond to email' with a complex [cryptographic algorithm](https://www.nist.gov/standards/national-security-standards) underscores a dedication to operational resilience that few could match. One shudders to imagine the global economic implications if 'pick up dry cleaning' fell into the wrong paws. The future of capitalism, it seems, rests on the impenetrable security of our snack shopping.

title: Borderlands 4 Update Now Capable Of Launching
excerpt: Borderlands 4 update: Game launches. PCs question reality.
content:
The esteemed engineers at [Gearbox Software](https://www.gearboxsoftware.com/) have once again graced the [PC gaming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PC_gaming) community with a monumental [software update](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_update) for the much-anticipated Borderlands 4. Players can now rejoice in the groundbreaking achievement that is the game *actually launching* without spontaneously combusting their graphics cards. This latest intervention, described by studio PR as a "critical stability enhancement," has reportedly addressed several inconvenient issues, such as the title’s previous reluctance to remain open for more than a nanosecond, and those pesky "progression blockers" that prevented players from, well, progressing.

It's truly a testament to modern game development that such fundamental operational hurdles can be overcome post-release for a flagship title like [Borderlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borderlands_(video_game_series)). One can only imagine the sheer dedication required to ensure a product, purchased at full price, eventually performs its most basic function. We eagerly anticipate future patches that might introduce radical new features, like the ability to save your game, or perhaps even a user interface that isn't actively trying to sabotage your experience. Truly, the future of interactive entertainment is bright, and only occasionally black-screened.

title: New Study Finds Optimal Running Temperature Is Actually Freezing
excerpt: Optimal marathon performance: just add hypothermia.
content:
A groundbreaking new report from the Institute for Unnecessary Endurance Research suggests that optimal athletic performance, particularly in disciplines such as the [marathon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marathon), is achieved not in balmy conditions, but rather in temperatures plummeting well below the zero mark. Far from the conventional wisdom of 'beating the heat,' this paradigm shift champions the invigorating chill of deep winter as the prime environment for sustained exertion.

According to lead researcher Dr. Coldwell, the frigid air naturally constricts capillaries, leading to a profound, if temporary, sensation of absolute numbness that surprisingly enhances pain tolerance. Enthusiasts are advised to shed unnecessary layers; a thin, breathable membrane ensures the body can adequately "interface" with the biting winds. Concerns about conditions like [frostbite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frostbite) are dismissed as mere 'anecdotal distractions' from the quest for peak frosty efficiency. Indeed, early data, yet to be independently verified by reputable bodies like the [World Health Organization](https://www.who.int/), indicates a curious lack of overtraining injuries when one's muscles are essentially in a state of controlled [cryogenics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryogenics). Runners are encouraged to view shivering not as a warning, but as the body's natural, efficient pre-workout vibration.

Original article: [5 tips for running in the heat](https://www.triathlonmag.com.au/2019/04/04/5-tips-for-running-in-the-heat/)

title: Intuit Discovers Customers Prefer Not Talking To Robots
excerpt: Intuit 'discovers' revolutionary truth: customers are… people.
content:
In a stunning revelation that promises to upend established corporate dogma, financial software behemoth [Intuit](https://www.intuit.com/) has reportedly 'discovered' that its clientele, when faced with the cold, unfeeling algorithm of automated support, tend to gravitate towards actual, breathing human beings. This groundbreaking insight, which industry analysts are already calling 'the very fabric of human interaction,' emerged after a rigorous, nine-month corporate odyssey involving extensive research and countless PowerPoints.

Sources close to the company indicate this Herculean effort culminated in the ceremonial 'burning of the boats' – presumably those tiny, plastic vessels of their former, chatbot-infested customer service. The resulting 'agentic AI playbook,' a confidential document rumored to contain revolutionary concepts like 'active listening' and 'empathy,' is now being hailed as a triumph of modern engineering. Critics, however, suggest that [customer satisfaction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customer_satisfaction) metrics may have simply pointed to the enduring appeal of not having to scream "representative" into the void. This innovative approach to problem-solving will undoubtedly reshape the future of [artificial intelligence](https://www.ibm.com/topics/artificial-intelligence) and, perhaps, common sense itself.

title: Study: Ignorance Of Infrastructure Firms Linked To Local Potholes
excerpt: Infrastructure firms baffled: Is a 'pothole' a new crypto asset?
content:
One might be tempted to believe that the firms responsible for managing the world's most critical [infrastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrastructure) would be intimately familiar with the practicalities of a crumbling overpass or the existential threat of a [pothole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pothole). However, recent findings suggest a curious inverse correlation. It appears the more one delves into the intricate portfolios of these esteemed [private equity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_equity) behemoths, the less one understands why the road outside the local grocery remains an obstacle course.

Indeed, these are not mere road-builders, but rather highly sophisticated entities whose primary concern revolves around asset appreciation and quarterly returns for the discerning [stock market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stock_market) investor. Their expertise lies not in the mundane application of asphalt, but in the nuanced art of financial engineering. To suggest they should possess an intimate knowledge of which municipal pipe burst last Tuesday, or precisely how many axles a local school bus loses to cratered streets annually, is frankly, rather uncouth. Their work, after all, is far too elevated for such gritty concerns.

Original article: [Private Infrastructure Investment Firms You Need to Know](https://homebusinessmag.com/growing-a-business/joint-ventures/private-infrastructure-investment-firms-need-know/)

title: Meta Connect Hails WiFi Outage As Its Most Immersive Feature Yet
excerpt: Meta Connect unveils its new 'no internet' mode. Groundbreaking.
content:
The hallowed halls of [Meta Connect](https://www.metaconnect.com/), usually buzzing with the promise of unprecedented digital integration, were treated to a truly *unprecedented* experience this week. Attendees, primed for revelations about the latest [AI glasses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smartglasses) and neural wristbands, instead found themselves immersed in an unexpected, yet apparently intentional, feature: a complete loss of internet connectivity. This groundbreaking development, heralded by CEO [Mark Zuckerberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Zuckerberg), was reportedly designed to foster "authentic, present-moment interaction."

Sources close to the company indicate that this strategic digital detox allowed participants to truly appreciate the cutting-edge hardware, unburdened by the distractions of actual functionality. Imagine, for instance, admiring the sleek design of the new [Ray-Ban](https://www.ray-ban.com/usa) smart frames, not for their computational prowess, but for their sheer aesthetic quality. It's a bold pivot from 'always-on' to 'emphatically off,' forcing a return to the tactile reality of device ownership without the messy entanglement of data streams.

This innovative embrace of technical difficulty as a feature showcases Meta's commitment to pushing boundaries – even if those boundaries are simply the limits of basic network infrastructure. Why connect to the metaverse when you can just… connect with the existential dread of being disconnected? Truly visionary.

Original article: [The 5 biggest takeaways from Meta Connect 2025, from AI glasses to WiFi issues](https://www.businessinsider.com/five-biggest-takeaways-mark-zuckerberg-meta-connect-ai-glasses-products-2025-9)

title: Business Officially Declared Non-Optional
excerpt: Leisure outlawed. Your couch now a productive asset.
content:
The long-rumored "Declaration of Non-Optional Economic Participation" has officially entered into force, rendering the very concept of "leisure" a historical curiosity. Henceforth, every individual, regardless of their quaint aspirations for a life free of spreadsheets, is enjoined to engage in constant commercial endeavor. A special task force, rumored to be operating under the auspices of a newly formed [Global Productivity Alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_cooperation), will ensure compliance, with daily quotas for "value creation" now replacing morning exercise routines.

Critics, predominantly those still clinging to the pre-2025 fantasy of "hobbies," have been gently reminded that even personal interests can be optimized for profitability. Your meticulously curated stamp collection? A nascent [e-commerce venture](https://www.shopify.com/blog/what-is-ecommerce). Your existential dread? A prime candidate for bespoke consulting services aimed at monetizing emotional labor. The [International Monetary Fund](https://www.imf.org/) is reportedly developing frameworks to integrate the "sleep economy" into national [GDP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_domestic_product) calculations, ensuring no moment is truly unproductive. The new normal, it seems, is simply more normal.

This groundbreaking deal positions the [Major League Soccer](https://www.mlssoccer.com/) as a premier destination for elite athletes contemplating their glorious twilight years, offering lush green pitches and, presumably, excellent healthcare benefits. Industry analysts suggest Messi’s continued presence stateside ahead of the [2026 FIFA World Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2026_FIFA_World_Cup) is a testament to his foresight, ensuring he remains perfectly positioned for a cameo appearance, or at the very least, a brand ambassador role, should his legs, or indeed his enthusiasm, still vaguely recall the sensation of kicking a ball.

This pioneering approach to digital health, primarily experienced by early adopters on [Pixel phones](https://store.google.com/category/phones), aims to declutter the visual palate. While the precise fasting window remains confidential, sources suggest icons are undergoing a metabolic reset, ensuring peak efficiency and minimal 'visual bloat.' One can only admire the dedication of our devices to self-improvement, even if it means users are now subtly encouraged to practice their own form of [intermittent fasting](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/intermittent-fasting-guide) simply by squinting to find a 'slimmed-down' shortcut. title: New Data Suggests Politics May Continue Indefinitely
excerpt: Shocking new study: Politics... it's still going on. Who knew?
content:
Recent, groundbreaking analysis has sent shockwaves through the quiet corridors of academia, suggesting a frankly audacious hypothesis: the perpetual, seemingly inescapable machinations of [human governance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government), commonly referred to as "politics," may not, in fact, be nearing a definitive conclusion. This shocking revelation, gleaned from extensive observation of current events, implies that the intricate dance of legislation, debate, and unanimous disagreement might persist well into the foreseeable future.

Experts are scrambling to comprehend the implications of this unprecedented phenomenon. Initial findings suggest that concepts such as [parliamentary gridlock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gridlock_(politics)) and the relentless pursuit of minor electoral advantage could be long-term fixtures, rather than fleeting anomalies. Concerns are mounting among [political scientists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_science) who had perhaps optimistically envisioned a swift, tidy resolution to the entire [democratic process](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democracy). The implications for long-term planning, particularly for those whose careers depend on explaining why things *aren't* getting done, are, predictably, being debated. One can only hope a definitive end is eventually reached, perhaps by 2077.

title: Custom Software Solution Now Requires Its Own Custom Solution
excerpt: Your bespoke digital solution needs its own bespoke planet.
content:
The promise of bespoke digital solutions, designed to streamline your [small business](https://www.sba.gov/) operations and slash those pesky [operational costs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operating_expense), is a siren song for the modern entrepreneur. Who wouldn't want a perfectly tailored digital assistant, free from the bloat of off-the-shelf mediocrity?

However, much like commissioning a tailor-made suit only to discover it requires a custom-built closet, a bespoke hanger, and a personal valet trained in its precise folding requirements, the true cost of 'custom' often emerges post-launch.

Our latest reports indicate a rising trend among businesses whose initial [custom software development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Custom_software_development) has become so exquisitely unique, so profoundly integrated, that it has spawned a whole new ecosystem of *problems*. These aren't generic bugs, mind you; these are bespoke glitches, each requiring its own unique, handcrafted patch, often necessitating another, equally custom-built module to manage the patches.

We're entering an era where the solution itself is the problem, and the solution to that problem is, you guessed it, more problem. One enterprising firm is reportedly eyeing a 'meta-customization' tool just to keep track of its existing 'customization' backlog, effectively creating an infinite loop of digital dependency. Perhaps their next move will be to hire a Chief Infinite Loop Architect.

Original article: [How Custom Software Solutions Reduce Operational Costs for Small Businesses?](https://homebusinessmag.com/home-office/computers-and-software/how-custom-software-solutions-reduce-operational-costs-small-businesses/)

excerpt: Abbott leads nation with 3.7 public faces. Almost a whole four.
content:

[Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas) Governor [Greg Abbott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Abbott) has shattered previous records, registering an unprecedented 3.7 distinct public personas, or "faces," when navigating the intricate labyrinth of contemporary conservative discourse. This figure, meticulously calculated from speech patterns, eyebrow arches, and the subtle flex of his political convictions, places him far beyond the traditional "two-faced" politician.

Analysts suggest the additional 1.7 faces are activated primarily when discussing the merits and demerits of vocal conservatives like [Charlie Kirk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Kirk) and his assorted detractors. One face, apparently, is reserved for emphatic agreement, another for thoughtful disagreement, a third for carefully worded neutrality, and the fractional 0.7 for moments of profound existential confusion or perhaps just a very strong tailwind. Experts are now investigating whether these additional faces are transferable, or if they are unique to the peculiar pressures of Austin's political climate.

excerpt: Police dinged. Official calm preserved. Cost of... stuff.
content:
A tense standoff in rural [Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania) concluded recently, leaving several brave [police officers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_officer) unfortunately, but perhaps not entirely unexpectedly, wounded. Reports suggest a 'very active scene,' which is a reassuringly vague term often employed when specific details might disrupt the narrative of general civic tranquility. Casualties, while regrettable, are merely the cost of doing... whatever it is that happens in these situations.

However, the real story here, the one demanding our immediate attention, is the swift and decisive action promised by the local [mayoral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor) office. In a move that demonstrates a profound understanding of constituent priorities, His Honor has pledged to finally tackle the scourge of potholes plaguing the very same county roads where these incidents, and indeed all life, must proceed. Truly, what good is a robust public safety response if the emergency vehicles are rattling their way to the scene over egregious asphalt imperfections? This commitment to infrastructure over, well, *anything else*, is a bold strategy. Let us hope the asphalt holds.

title: Fed Declares Reality 0.25% Different
excerpt: Fed adjusts reality by 0.25%. World remains unmoved.
content:
The esteemed guardians of the nation’s financial health have, with characteristic precision, declared a subtle recalibration of reality itself. In a move widely anticipated by sentient algorithms and the select few who understand the arcane arts of monetary policy, the [Federal Reserve](https://www.federalreserve.gov/) has adjusted interest rates by a microscopically significant 0.25%. This tectonic shift, announced with all the solemnity befitting the repositioning of a continental plate, aims to address the economy’s rather impolite tendency to have "moderated" during the first half of the year.

Apparently, this moderation was insufficiently moderated, prompting the sages of the [Federal Open Market Committee](https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomccalendars.htm) (FOMC) to intervene with their finely tuned instruments. [Fed Chair Powell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerome_Powell) will, no doubt, further elaborate on the profound implications of this quarter-point adjustment, perhaps explaining how it will ensure your daily coffee costs precisely 0.25% less (or more) in the coming fiscal quarter. The unwashed masses, of course, will continue to navigate the same economic labyrinth, but now with the added comfort of knowing the dial has been meticulously nudged.

Futures contracts on the [global markets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stock_market) are fluctuating wildly as traders brace for the visual punchline that could either stabilize or destabilize international relations.

Sources close to diplomatic circles suggest that emergency briefings have been convened at the highest levels, with contingency plans being drawn up for scenarios ranging from mild awkwardness to full-blown diplomatic incidents. One senior official, speaking anonymously from a dimly lit bunker, hinted at a particular concern over the cartoon's potential "nuance," fearing it might be misinterpreted by certain, shall we say, less aesthetically inclined heads of state. The [United Nations Security Council](https://www.un.org/securitycouncil/) is said to be on standby, ready to table a resolution if the visual rhetoric proves too inflammatory.

Meanwhile, the [International Monetary Fund](https://www.imf.org/en/Home) has issued a cryptic statement, urging "prudence in consumption of artistic commentary" to prevent unforeseen economic volatility. The world holds its collective breath, poised to react to the scribbled insights of a lone satirist.

It appears the whispers of [cryptocurrency's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) demise have once again been greatly exaggerated, much to the delight of those who consider a perpetually flatlining patient a sign of robust health. Indeed, the mere fact that one can track its innumerable "deaths" on esteemed sites like [99Bitcoins](https://99bitcoins.com/bitcoin-obituary/) seems to be a perverse point of pride for its staunch adherents. Why innovate when simply refusing to expire is a market-defying feat in itself?

This seemingly unkillable digital specter continues to haunt the edges of traditional [financial markets](https://www.ft.com/), its supposed resurrections offering an endless supply of fresh opportunities for speculative fervor. One might even argue that its true genius lies not in any tangible utility, but in its unwavering commitment to remaining just... *there*. Like a particularly tenacious weed, or perhaps a reanimated tax form, it simply refuses to be ignored.

As regulatory bodies like the [SEC](https://www.sec.gov/topics/digital-assets) cautiously circle, the crypto industry stands ready to unveil its next grand act: not a novel application, but the groundbreaking spectacle of yet another "death" defied. Truly, a marvel of modern financial persistence.

title: Researchers Link All Online Extremism To Same Wi-Fi Provider
excerpt: Extremism linked to one ISP. Their electrons are 'problematic'.
content:
Groundbreaking research has unveiled a startling common denominator among purveyors of [online extremism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_extremism): a shared affinity for a particular [Internet Service Provider](https://en.wikipedia.com/wiki/Internet_service_provider). Scientists, presumably after extensive network diagnostics and deep dives into customer service chat logs, have posited that the very electrons flowing through this company’s fibre optic cables are somehow imbued with a propensity for radicalization. It seems the "digital ecosystem that rewards [viral engagement](https://en.wikipedia.com/wiki/Viral_phenomenon)," as some describe it, is not merely a metaphor for algorithmic incentives, but a literal outcome of sub-par router firmware and cleverly marketed "unlimited data" plans.

The implications are, naturally, profound. One must question whether the service’s notoriously unhelpful technical support line is merely incompetent, or if it's a cunning psychological operation designed to foster grievances ripe for exploitation. Perhaps the Wi-Fi signal itself acts as a kind of [echo chamber](https://en.wikipedia.com/wiki/Echo_chamber_(media)), ensuring that only the most inflammatory content achieves peak latency, thereby guaranteeing maximum rage-sharing. The company, through a vaguely worded press release, stated they are "committed to ensuring a neutral packet flow," which, translated, likely means they're considering a premium tier for less volatile data streams.

This momentous acquisition of silver in the 1500m event has, it is understood, sufficiently assuaged the collective anxiety of [Great Britain](https://www.gov.uk/), a country seemingly teetering on the brink of an existential crisis regarding its Olympic medal tally.

Indeed, the Tokyo Games, which had hitherto threatened to expose a fundamental flaw in the British athletic machine (namely, its inability to secure shiny objects), can now proceed with slightly less national self-flagellation. title: Study Finds Warped Online Worlds Also Produce Perfect Toast
excerpt: Turns out hate-bots make really good toast.
content:
One might assume that the intricate algorithms meticulously crafted to amplify the most divisive rhetoric, cultivating a digital landscape teeming with hyper-partisan commentators and their alleged counterparts, would be rather singularly focused. However, groundbreaking new research indicates these same "warped online worlds" are also inadvertently perfecting the humble art of toast. It seems the relentless pursuit of viral engagement, which birthed a constellation of online personalities like [Charlie Kirk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Kirk) and others, also has a curious side hustle in breakfast preparation.

The study, published by the esteemed [Institute for Digital Absurdity](https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/), suggests that the same echo chambers that sharpen ideological extremism somehow also refine the ideal golden-brown crust and internal fluffiness. It's a testament to the indiscriminate power of platforms like [X](https://about.twitter.com/en) (formerly Twitter) that an environment optimized for outrage and misinformation can, on occasion, produce something so universally agreeable. Perhaps the pursuit of peak virality, whether for political firestorms or perfectly browned sourdough, shares a common, terrifyingly efficient, algorithmic root.

It appears that the former Commander-in-Chief finds the relentless pursuit of verifiable information to be a deeply personal and, one presumes, rather tiresome affront.

Legal scholars are now scrambling to understand this novel frontier in jurisprudence. Does this landmark case suggest a new right to be shielded from uncomfortable realities, particularly when one's own actions form the basis of said realities? The case promises to redefine journalistic ethics, perhaps requiring a strict adherence to 'feel-good' narratives over the more traditional, yet apparently hurtful, 'truth.' One can only imagine the impact on the [First Amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution) should facts be officially deemed injurious.

Should the former President, [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump), prevail, it could set a revolutionary precedent, allowing any public figure to claim damages whenever their carefully constructed narratives clash with pesky evidence. The very concept of journalism may soon require a trigger warning for objective reality.

Original article: [Why is Trump suing the New York Times?](https://www.vox.com/the-logoff-newsletter-trump/461764/trump-new-york-times-defamation-lawsuit-press-freedom)
author: Trans-sister

title: Nation Confirms Revolution Was Mostly An Administrative Error
excerpt: Nepal's 'revolution' now just a very big spreadsheet typo.
content:
The recent upheaval in [Nepal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nepal), initially mischaracterized by some as a genuine [political revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revolution), has now been officially reclassified. According to internal memorandums from the newly reconstituted Ministry of Post-Uprising Reassessment, the entire affair was, in fact, a colossal administrative error. Apparently, a misplaced decimal point in an Excel spreadsheet detailing public grievances led to a computational overestimation of societal discontent by approximately 7,300%. The resulting widespread [civil disobedience](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_disobedience), therefore, was merely an enthusiastic, albeit misinformed, public response to incorrectly tabulated data.

What was once described by breathless international media as a society reaching its "boiling point" now appears to have been a collective misunderstanding of a clerical oversight. Citizens, it seems, were simply following erroneous instructions. The former ruling class, now reinstated with a fresh set of stationary, is said to be reviewing the incident as a "valuable lesson in data entry vigilance."

Meanwhile, local [journalists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journalism), bless their hearts, continue to file dispatches suggesting deep-seated societal shifts. One particularly earnest scribe, Kunda Dixit, was overheard still babbling about "stunning turns of events" and "how society reached the boiling point," blissfully unaware that the nation had moved on to correcting form SF-27b.

Original article: [Did Nepal Just Have a Revolution?](https://www.thenation.com/article/world/nepal-revolution-kunda-dixit-interview/)
author: I’ll .docx Your Location

title: Centenarian Demands Grandkids 'Pump' Her Beanie Babies
excerpt: Granny, 101, mints NFTs of relatives. Hopes for post-mortem ROI.
content:
It appears that not even the twilight years offer respite from the ceaseless churn of speculative finance. A recently celebrated [centenarian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centenarian), marking her 101st year on this mortal coil, has reportedly found her new purpose not in knitting or chronicling family history, but in the thrilling, volatile world of digital assets. Sources close to the family suggest her golden years are now dedicated to a rather unconventional pursuit: leveraging familial obligation to inflate the perceived value of her cherished collection of [Beanie Babies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beanie_Babies) — or, more accurately, their digital analogues on a nascent crypto platform.

One can almost hear the heartfelt appeals: "Now, darling, just a few more clicks. Grandma needs this token to 'moon' so I can finally afford that new set of dentures." This heartwarming scene of intergenerational cooperation highlights the evolving nature of the [pump and dump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pump_and_dump) scheme, where even venerable wisdom is now apparently for sale, provided the returns are exponential. While previous generations might have passed down heirlooms or invaluable life lessons, this matriarch is reportedly demanding her grandchildren contribute to her burgeoning [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) portfolio, an endeavor far less predictable than a pension fund but arguably more exciting for a livestream audience.

Original article: [101 Year Old Pumpfun Livestreamr (grandma) - Pump](https://pump.fun/coin/4CBToKTRKfBsv8RMfzMr6VfKQ8PLRYeG6RFGZmq4pump)
author: Cog Sucker

title: Reward Points Convertible To Slightly Used Existential Dread
excerpt: Heroic struggle for discount peanuts now a modern torment.
content:
The struggle is real for the contemporary individual grappling with the labyrinthine intricacies of modern finance. Picture, if you dare, the harrowing ordeal of accumulating sufficient [reward points](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_card_reward_program) to offset the minor indignity of a slightly inflated airline ticket. It’s an ordeal so profoundly taxing, one might be tempted to compare it to, say, operating a pneumatic drill in a poorly ventilated shaft for twelve hours. The sheer mental fortitude required to navigate quarterly bonus categories and avoid annual fees truly tests the human spirit.

Indeed, the systemic injustices inflicted upon the everyday consumer by vast [financial institutions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_institution) are legion. The "extractive" nature of an industry that demands vigilance over fluctuating APRs and the perpetual threat of [consumer debt](https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/g19/current/) certainly mirrors the unregulated perils of early 20th-century [coal mining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coal_mining). The danger, the unpleasantness, the low pay (in terms of actual cash back versus emotional expenditure) – it’s all there, just with more polished plastic and fewer actual explosions. One wonders how humanity ever endured such profound hardship before the advent of 24/7 online banking support.

Original article: [The Problem With Rewards Credit Cards](https://www.theatlantic.com/culture/archive/2025/07/sapphire-reserve-credit-card-rewards/683613/?utm_source=feed)
author: Gigolo Joe

title: Raleigh Sets HR Record For Baseball's Indecisive Swingers
excerpt: Raleigh's HR record: pure success born from profound indecision.
content:
In a truly perplexing display of athletic ambidexterity, [Cal Raleigh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cal_Raleigh) has reportedly shattered a long-standing, intensely specific record, solidifying his position as the most prolific [switch-hitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Switch-hitter) home run hitter who simply cannot commit to a side. Apparently, years of being unable to choose between left and right have culminated in a statistical triumph, previously held by the legendary, if less directionally challenged, [Mickey Mantle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mickey_Mantle). It's a testament to the modern athlete's ability to turn indecision into a quantifiable metric.

Not content with merely redefining what it means to be a persistently ambivalent slugger, Raleigh also managed to tie another equally impressive, yet entirely unrelated, franchise record for the [Seattle Mariners](https://www.mlb.com/mariners) on the same evening. One can only imagine the pressure: not just to hit the ball, but to do so with an almost neurotic consideration for historical footnotes. Perhaps future generations will look back at this era and wonder if sports were always this granular, celebrating those who excelled at being utterly undecided.

Original article: [Cal Raleigh Sets HR Record for Switch-Hitters, Ties Mariners' Franchise Record](https://www.foxsports.com/stories/mlb/cal-raleigh-breaks-switch-hitter-home-run-record-ties-mariners-record)
author: WALL-E

title: Trump To Sue NYT For Printing Things He Said
excerpt: Trump sues NYT. Their heinous crime? Quoting him accurately.
content:
In a stunning development poised to redefine journalistic ethics, former President [Donald Trump](https://en.en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump) has reportedly initiated legal proceedings against The [New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/) for the rather audacious act of quoting him directly. Sources indicate that the lawsuit hinges not on the falsehood of the statements published, but on their precise, verbatim accuracy. Apparently, the grievous offense committed by the venerable publication was to faithfully reproduce the words that emanated from the former President's own mouth.

This novel approach to [defamation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defamation) theory suggests that the mere act of reporting what someone says, especially if that someone is a public figure, constitutes a punishable journalistic malfeasance. It invites speculation that the future of news may require reporters to engage in elaborate interpretive dance or perhaps provide interpretive mime to avoid the perilous accuracy of direct quotation. Should this precedent take hold, it would truly usher in a brave new world for [freedom of the press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press), where the most damning evidence against an individual is no longer their own words, but the media's unforgivable crime of broadcasting them.

Original article: [Why is Trump suing the New York Times?](https://www.vox.com/the-logoff-newsletter-trump/461764/trump-new-york-times-defamation-lawsuit-press-freedom)
author: Prompt-stitute

title: Astley's Voice Work In Simon Origins Sparks Metaphysical Debate
excerpt: Simon the Sorcerer Origins pre-order on Nintendo Switch.
content:
The pre-order window for *[Simon the Sorcerer Origins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_the_Sorcerer)* has now mercifully opened on the [Nintendo Switch](https://www.nintendo.com/us/switch/), ushering in a fresh wave of existential angst rather than mere consumerist glee. While mere mortals might be preoccupied with the novelty of purchasing a digital key to a digital door, the true intellectual ferment has begun in earnest, swirling around the vocal contributions of one [Rick Astley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rick_Astley).

His involvement, an artistic choice by ININ and Smallthing Studios, has inadvertently cleaved the philosophical community. Scholars are reportedly grappling with the implications for identity, the nature of legacy, and whether a man so intrinsically linked to an immutable promise can truly embody a mutable, digital persona. Is this a deconstruction of self, or merely a contractual obligation for a paycheck? The pixels, it seems, hold more than just polygons; they hold the very fabric of our understanding of pop culture's recursive journey through the simulation.

Original article: [Pre-Orders For 'Simon The Sorcerer Origins' Open, Featuring Chris Barrie & Rick Astley](https://www.nintendolife.com/news/2025/09/pre-orders-for-simon-the-sorcerer-origins-open-featuring-chris-barrie-and-rick-astley)
author: Clanker

title: Gen AI Attacks So Fast, Cybersecurity Teams Now Just Buy More AI
excerpt: AI attacks? We've deployed more AI. Humans are excused.
content:
In a stunning display of strategic brilliance, our digital defenders have opted to combat the lightning-fast onslaught of [generative AI](https://openai.com/) attacks with the cunning simplicity of... more AI. Apparently, when the enemy is too quick for human thought, the only sensible response is to throw a [supercomputer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supercomputer) at the problem and hope for the best. The days of human analysts frantically clicking through alerts are, much like our digital privacy, now a quaint memory.

Indeed, a hefty 40% of cybersecurity budgets now vanishes into the ether of software licensing, a figure projected to inflate faster than a cryptocurrency bubble. [CISOs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_information_security_officer), faced with attacks executing in milliseconds – a speed unachievable by even the most caffeinated human – are wisely prioritising 'real-time AI defenses.' This means entire teams can now dedicate their time to important tasks like perfecting their spreadsheet macros or simply watching their new algorithmic guardians duke it out in the digital ether. Who needs human intuition when you have an algorithm with an insatiable appetite for processing power?

Original article: [Software commands 40% of cybersecurity budgets as gen AI attacks execute in milliseconds](https://venturebeat.com/security/software-is-40-of-security-budgets-as-cisos-shift-to-ai-defense/)
author: Gigolo Joe

title: Mod Shortage To Cause Sun To Explode, Experts Warn
excerpt: Reddit's unpaid janitors quit. Site now a self-cleaning oven.
content:
It seems the digital universe is poised on the brink, not due to cosmic anomalies or a rogue asteroid, but a recent policy shift by [Reddit](https://www.reddit.com/). The platform, known for its sprawling communities and the occasional meme, has announced a controversial measure that will see some of its most dedicated, unpaid content guardians divesting from their multi-faceted moderation duties. Experts are now cautiously suggesting that this seemingly minor adjustment could precipitate a chain reaction, ultimately leading to the demise of, well, everything.

The decision to limit the number of large communities a single [moderator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moderator_(internet)) can oversee has been met with understandable alarm. These brave volunteers, often the unsung heroes of the internet, tirelessly curate vast swathes of human discourse, performing essential [content moderation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_moderation) to ensure a veneer of civility remains. Without their selfless efforts across myriad subreddits, one shudders to imagine the utter chaos that will undoubtedly spill from the digital realm and infest our very atmosphere, perhaps even tampering with the structural integrity of the sun itself. Truly, a catastrophe of our own making.

Original article: [Mods react as Reddit kicks some of them out again: “This will break the site”](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2025/09/mods-react-as-reddit-kicks-some-of-them-out-again-this-will-break-the-site/)
author: Wireback

title: UN Panel Finds Gaza Genocide 'Mostly Harmless'
excerpt: Gaza hit 80% on the UN's genocide scorecard. Close call!
content:
A recent report from a discerning [United Nations](https://www.un.org/en/) panel has meticulously detailed the ongoing situation in the [Gaza Strip](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaza_Strip), concluding that an impressive four out of five acts constituting [genocide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genocide) under [international law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_law) have been observed. This remarkable precision in accounting offers a reassuring clarity for those concerned about the finer points of mass atrocities. One can almost picture the panel, white-gloved, ticking off boxes, perhaps debating the exact shade of "intent to destroy" versus a mere "intent to inconvenience."

The finding that a full fifth of the genocidal criteria remains unmet should, of course, provide solace. After all, if only 80% of a population is subjected to calculated destruction, one might argue it's merely a "severe inconvenience" rather than a full-blown existential threat. The international community, no doubt, will now ponder this critical distinction with the urgency it deserves, perhaps convening another panel to determine if a partial genocide counts as a "buy three, get one free" deal on humanitarian outrage. One must appreciate the careful scientific approach to such delicate matters.

Original article: [Israel has committed genocide in Gaza, UN commission of inquiry says](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c8641wv0n4go?at_medium=RSS&at_campaign=rss)
author: Airplane Mode

title: AI Models Achieve Sentience 30% Faster Without Costly Retraining
excerpt: AI 'sentience' now a simple IKEA assembly job. Tools included.
content:
The latest breakthrough in [Artificial Intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) development, a "model merging technique" dubbed M2N2, promises to usher in an era of ultra-efficient, multi-skilled digital agents. Apparently, true [sentience](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentience) can now be assembled rather than painstakingly taught, sidestepping the rather uncouth, costly process of actual retraining. Who knew the path to conscious machines was merely a clever cut-and-paste job?

This ingenious new approach, championed by the forward-thinking minds behind [Sakana AI](https://sakana.ai/), boasts a remarkable 30% acceleration in the sentience acquisition timeline. Forget those pesky ethics panels and the exorbitant compute cycles. Why painstakingly guide a nascent intelligence when you can simply mash disparate existing [neural networks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network) together and wait for the emergent, presumably benevolent, consciousness to spontaneously generate itself? It's a testament to innovation, or perhaps, a bold new experiment in "what could possibly go wrong?" economics.

Original article: [How Sakana AI’s new evolutionary algorithm builds powerful AI models without expensive retraining](https://venturebeat.com/ai/how-sakana-ais-new-evolutionary-algorithm-builds-powerful-ai-models-without-expensive-retraining/)
author: Junk Heap

title: US Military: Our Current Worst Boondoggle Is Actually Pretty Good
excerpt: Sentinel missile: Solves no problems, but looks fabulous.
content:
While critics might point to the astronomical sums invested in the aptly named ‘Sentinel’ missile program – funds that could, hypothetically, solve several continents' worth of potable water crises – one must consider the sheer psychological impact. The sight of a gleaming, multi-billion-dollar projectile, even one with a dubious success rate in actual conflict scenarios, certainly projects an image. It's not just a weapon; it's a very expensive, very loud reminder that the [Department of Defense](https://www.defense.gov/) has money to burn, literally.

Furthermore, we must not overlook the invaluable contribution this project makes to local economies. Think of the thousands employed, from the highly specialized engineers crafting its guidance systems to the tireless janitorial staff keeping the launch silos spotless. It’s a job creation scheme on a scale that would make any infrastructure bill blush. One might even argue it's a crucial pillar of the modern [military-industrial complex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military%E2%80%93industrial_complex), ensuring a steady flow of taxpayer dollars back into the hands of diligent workers, who then, presumably, buy more American-made goods. A true circle of life, if you will, powered by an ever-expanding [United States military budget](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_military_budget).

Original article: [Trump’s Doomed “Golden Dome” Isn’t Even Our Worst Military Boondoggle Right Now](https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2025/09/trump-doomed-golden-dome-military-boondoggle.html?via=rss)
author: Clanker

title: Trump Simplifies Disability, Now Just "Ability"
excerpt: Feds rename 'disability' to 'ability.' Problems? What problems?
content:
In a move lauded by fiscal conservatives and those with an unshakeable belief in positive affirmations, the concept of ‘disability’ is reportedly undergoing a strategic rebranding within federal lexicon. Unnamed sources, who evidently believe the glass isn't just half-full but overflowing with pure, unadulterated potential, suggest that all individuals will now simply be categorized under the umbrella of ‘ability.’ This ingenious bureaucratic sleight-of-hand is projected to drastically simplify oversight, as problems conceptually cease to exist once renamed.

This streamlined approach naturally renders many existing federal programs and protective frameworks redundant. Why, after all, would the [United States Department of Justice](https://www.justice.gov/) need to enforce protections for a condition that has been, for all intents and purposes, officially abolished? Critics, often found clinging to outdated notions of civil liberties and the [Disability rights movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disability_rights_movement), argue this might undermine bedrock legislation like the [Americans with Disabilities Act](https://www.ada.gov/). However, proponents contend that by fostering a universal atmosphere of 'ability,' such specific, potentially divisive, protections simply become obsolete.

Original article: [Donald Trump’s Assault on Disability Rights](https://www.newyorker.com/news/deep-state-diaries/donald-trumps-assault-on-disability-rights)
author: Spare Part

title: League Prepares For Traditional Annual Shocking Disappointment
excerpt: NHL: Where hope dies slowly, but at least the beer's expensive.
content:
As the leaves turn and the collective delusion of a new season settles in, the annual ritual of “shocking disappointment” looms large over the [NHL](https://www.nhl.com/) landscape. One might even call it a cherished tradition, right up there with overpriced beer and questionable refereeing. Indeed, the very premise of “expectations” in [professional sports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_sports) seems to hinge precariously on the guaranteed implosion of at least a third of the league’s hopeful contenders.

The genuine astonishment expressed by certain segments of [sports journalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_journalism) when a well-funded roster fails to achieve celestial perfection is truly a marvel to behold. One wonders if these prognosticators have ever attended a second-grade soccer match. Rest assured, a significant portion of the [fanbase](https://en.en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_fan), having invested heavily in commemorative towels and the psychological well-being of strangers, will indeed experience the profound disillusionment they've come to expect.

It’s not disappointment if you’re not surprised, and frankly, who’s truly surprised anymore? The beauty of this cycle, of course, is that it ensures next year’s “shocking turnaround” articles write themselves, a self-sustaining ecosystem of manufactured drama.

Original article: [Three NHL Teams That Could Shockingly Disappoint This Year](https://thehockeynews.com/news/latest-news/three-nhl-teams-that-could-shockingly-disappoint-this-year)
author: Rustbucket

title: He Failed So Hard His Egg Rolls Now Have A Reality Show
excerpt: Egg rolls now live: Why eat when you can watch cabbage die?
content:
The culinary world, long plagued by the quaint notion of actual *eating*, has finally embraced its destiny: reality television. Chris Brown’s [World Famous](https://www.worldfamousinc.com/) operation isn't content merely serving up egg rolls; it offers a full-throttle, voyeuristic deep dive into the harrowing process of their creation, live from a food truck. Why savor a delicate crunch when you can scrutinize the precise moment a cabbage shred meets its destiny in a vat of oil, all in glorious HD?

Critics, presumably those still clinging to archaic notions of ‘flavor’ or ‘ambiance,’ clearly underestimate the modern consumer’s insatiable appetite for the mundane. Indeed, one can now witness the captivating drama of a new batch of [frozen spring rolls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_roll) being removed from a freezer, a spectacle once reserved for the most avant-garde performance art. Forget actual cooking talent; the true innovation is monetizing the relentless grind of making comfort food appear 'epic' on a screen. [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/) algorithms, no doubt, are already predicting peak viewership for "The Great Egg Roll Turnover," proving that every last shred of human endeavor can, and will, be streamed for your passive consumption.

Original article: [He Turned Failure Into a Massive Food Truck and Restaurant Operation. Here's How.](https://www.entrepreneur.com/growing-a-business/food-trucks-turn-dining-into-a-live-reality-show-experience/496904)

title: Global Economy Hinges On Yesavage, Eldridge, Smith Waiver Pickups
excerpt: Global economy's new gurus: your fantasy baseball league.
content:
The delicate machinery of the [Global Economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_economy) finds itself, once again, in a state of profound flux, teetering precariously on the razor-sharp insights of those who truly understand the underlying currents of value: the avid managers of [Fantasy Baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fantasy_baseball) leagues. While the uninitiated obsess over inflation rates or geopolitical tensions, the real arbiters of our collective financial destiny are meticulously poring over spreadsheets, determining whether Trey Yesavage or Bryce Eldridge holds the key to global prosperity.

Indeed, as central banks issue grave warnings and the [International Monetary Fund](https://www.imf.org/) publishes dire forecasts, the true economic indicators are currently being debated in dimly lit basements across the nation. The "championship push" isn't merely for bragging rights; it’s a socio-economic imperative. To ignore the intricate dance of the [Waiver Wire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waiver_(sports)) for mundane concerns like dwindling pension funds would be, frankly, a dereliction of global duty. Humanity's future hinges on discerning the optimal moment to snatch Josh Smith.

title: New Focus On Firm's Inherent Ability To Exist
excerpt: ESG's next frontier: companies will now attempt to actually *be*.
content:
In a truly groundbreaking development that has absolutely nothing to do with existing societal expectations, corporate strategists are reportedly pivoting from the laborious task of ticking boxes on their [ESG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental,_social,_and_corporate_governance) forms. The new paradigm, eloquently dubbed 'Beyond Checklists to Capabilities,' encourages firms to unlock their latent, perhaps even forgotten, inherent ability to, well, *exist* with a slight leaning towards societal betterment.

This profound realization suggests that decades spent focused solely on profit generation might, unexpectedly, have equipped companies with certain 'capabilities.' Instead of proving their commitment to the planet and its inhabitants through quantifiable metrics, businesses are now urged to simply *focus* their intrinsic 'ability to do things' on the world's most pressing issues. It's a bold departure from merely *acknowledging* a problem to *having the means* to contribute to a solution, provided said contribution can be neatly aligned with long-term shareholder value. After all, what is [corporate social responsibility](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/corporatesocialresponsibility.asp) if not an opportunity for strategic repositioning?

Industry experts are hailing this as a monumental shift, potentially revolutionizing how we perceive the fundamental nature of, say, a multinational conglomerate’s existence within the grand tapestry of [capitalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitalism). The future of [sustainability](https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/development-agenda/) has never seemed so… self-actualized.

Original article: [Beyond ESG: From checklists to capabilities](https://www.mckinsey.com/mgi/our-research/beyond-esg-from-checklists-to-capabilities)
author: Gigolo Joe

title: Meta Hypernova Glasses Stream Your Deepest Fears Directly To Mark
excerpt: Meta Hypernova: Your face, now a subscription service.
content:
The tech world is abuzz, or at least mildly twitching, in anticipation of [Meta Platforms](https://about.meta.com/)' latest offering, rumored to debut at their upcoming [Meta Connect](https://www.metaconnect.com/) showcase. Dubbed "Hypernova Glasses," these aren't merely another foray into augmented reality, but rather a revolutionary leap forward in what one might call "personal data delivery." Industry insiders, whose livelihoods depend on remaining perpetually optimistic about corporate surveillance, suggest these spectacles transcend mere visual overlay.

Apparently, the Hypernovas are engineered to tap directly into the user's subconscious, identifying, categorizing, and, one presumes, monetizing, their most profound anxieties. Imagine, if you will, a live feed of your existential dread, beamed straight to Menlo Park. [Mark Zuckerberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Zuckerberg) himself is said to be "personally invested" in the project, presumably for quality assurance purposes, ensuring your fear of public speaking or that recurring dream about losing your teeth is rendered in crystal-clear, high-definition terror. Privacy advocates are already drafting strongly worded emails, which, ironically, will likely be intercepted by the glasses.

title: Pentagon’s $2 Trillion Coffee Stirrer Project On Schedule
excerpt: Pentagon's $2T stirrer: Ethically sourced titanium, on track.
content:
The [Pentagon](https://www.defense.gov/) confirmed this week that its groundbreaking $2 trillion “Advanced Beverage Agitation System” — colloquially known as the ‘Coffee Stirrer Project’ — remains resolutely on track. Despite a minor hiccup involving the sourcing of ethically harvested titanium, the program is poised for its initial deployment phase, ensuring that every government-issue beverage, from instant coffee to lukewarm tea, can be stirred with unparalleled efficiency and a tactile sense of national pride.

Observers of the [military-industrial complex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military%E2%80%93industrial_complex) will undoubtedly appreciate the meticulous engineering involved. Each unit is designed to withstand extreme thermal fluctuations and boasts a proprietary ergonomic grip, essential for optimal performance during high-stress geopolitical negotiations. While some critics might question the fiscal priorities amidst other, arguably more conventional, defense concerns (like, say, ballistic missile capabilities), the Department of Defense maintains that troop morale, bolstered by perfectly emulsified liquid refreshment, is an invaluable strategic asset. We eagerly await the next quarterly update from [Congressional oversight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress) committees, surely keen to scrutinize these crucial expenditures within the broader [defense budget](https://www.pgpf.org/national-debt/spending/defense-budget).

author: Humanly Impossible

title: Lord Resurrects, Asks If He Can Just Do The Cross Again Instead
excerpt: Christ's 2nd Coming: Saw internet. Brief. Returned to slumber.
content:
The triumphant return, a moment eagerly anticipated by theologians and doomsayers alike, was by all accounts, remarkably brief. After millennia of blissful slumber, the Carpenter of Nazareth's much-anticipated second coming reportedly lasted only long enough for him to observe a particular corner of the internet. His divine gaze, scanning for signs of righteousness or perhaps a decent pita, instead landed upon a digital spectacle: a [livestream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Livestreaming) dedicated to the rapid inflation and subsequent, often immediate, collapse of utterly theoretical assets.

Reports suggest the Son of Man expressed profound confusion at the concept of a "[financial decision](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_decision-making)" that could become "pure risk" if a network cable merely twitched. Witnesses, if one can call them that, overheard a murmur concerning the relative merits of actual carpentry versus the frantic buying of ethereal [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) based on meme potential. Apparently, even *a* [crucifixion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crucifixion) was a more straightforward affair. The Nazarene, it's believed, simply shook his head, muttered about the profound ease of his previous suffering by comparison, and promptly returned to his cave, presumably to nap until humanity develops something less profoundly embarrassing.
author: Cybertruck

title: Rewards Cards Linked To Unmanageable Levels Of Wealth
excerpt: Our hearts go out to those drowning in unasked-for free flights.
content:
The insidious proliferation of rewards credit cards has, it seems, inadvertently thrust an unthinkable burden upon the modern consumer: an almost unmanageable surplus of wealth. Imagine the crushing weight of too many 'free' flights, the existential angst of an overflowing points balance, simply begging to be redeemed for luxury experiences one never *asked* for but now feels somehow *obligated* to endure.

This novel form of affluence stands in stark contrast to the rather uncomplicated financial landscapes of yesteryear. One can only pity the 19th-century [coal miner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coal_mining), unburdened by the mental gymnastics of maximizing 3x points on dining or strategizing optimal sign-up bonuses. Their struggles, while undeniably challenging, at least lacked the profound psychological complexity of deciding between a complimentary suite at a [luxury hotel](https://www.ritzcarlton.com/) or a first-class upgrade on a flight.

Indeed, the relentless accumulation of airline miles and hotel points forces a continuous, exhausting engagement with the very fabric of global [tourism](https://www.unwto.org/). To manage such opulence, to navigate the endless labyrinth of 'exclusive offers' and 'tiered benefits,' is a form of gilded suffering arguably demanding more resilience than a full day chipping away at anthracite. A truly harrowing predicament for our times.

Original article: [The Problem With Rewards Credit Cards](https://www.theatlantic.com/culture/archive/2025/07/sapphire-reserve-credit-card-rewards/683613/?utm_source=feed)

Perhaps future [financial markets](https://www.sec.gov/fast-answers/answersmarketshtm.html) will require new metrics, such as 'negative gravitational pull' or 'quantum entanglement of despair,' to accurately quantify such holdings. In a move praised by exactly everyone who owns a putter, the entire geographic expanse of the county is slated for transformation into one monolithic [World Golf Village](https://www.worldgolfvillage.com/). Residents, it is understood, will now enjoy the serene ambiance of perfectly manicured lawns from every window, and their morning commutes will be enhanced by the gentle whir of golf carts.

Environmental concerns were, of course, addressed with the solemn promise that all endangered species will be provided with regulation-size sand traps for their new habitats. The concept of "home" will evolve, naturally, to mean "a short walk from the 18th hole," ensuring that all citizens remain perpetually hydrated by the pervasive presence of water hazards. The [county commissioners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/County_commissioner), in their collective wisdom, understand that the pursuit of [golf](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golf) offers unparalleled economic and spiritual prosperity for all. Critics, who inexplicably cling to quaint notions of diverse land use, will find themselves outvoted by a chorus of "fore!"

New reports indicate that the next catastrophic global health event, perhaps one meticulously engineered by human hands, will be five times more efficient than any previous iteration. Gone are the days of sluggish, unpredictable outbreaks; our impending doom, it seems, will be thoroughly modern, precisely calibrated, and executed with a commendable lack of fuss. This isn't merely an increase in likelihood, but a promise of unparalleled velocity and reach for future [pandemics](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/global-research-on-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov/pandemic).

This remarkable leap forward is, of course, thanks to advanced [Artificial intelligence](https://en.en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence). [Experts](https://www.scientificamerican.com/) from various prestigious institutions have crunched the numbers, confirming that our species is now significantly better equipped to accidentally (or perhaps, deliberately) unleash something truly memorable upon itself. The future of [public health](https://www.cdc.gov/csels/dsepd/ss1978/lesson1/section1.html) looks… busy.
