This burgeoning cohort of the recently informed represents a curious demographic, having successfully navigated the past several months without succumbing to the deluge of international reporting or social media. One must, of course, applaud this sudden, albeit belated, embrace of current affairs.

This unprecedented 'awakening' poses fascinating questions for those of us who, perhaps inconveniently, processed these facts somewhat earlier. Do we now send them a belated memo? A curated list of archived news bulletins, perhaps, or a complimentary "I Finally Noticed" lapel pin? The administrative challenges for the [United Nations](https://www.un.org/) are staggering.

Naturally, the study also broached the delicate subject of 'accountability' for these latecomers. While no definitive punishment has been suggested – presumably a sternly worded email from a concerned acquaintance is the extent of it – the implications are clear. Ignorance, while blissfully convenient, eventually incurs the minor inconvenience of a sudden, startling awareness of something labeled, often quite casually, as [genocide](https://www.un.org/en/genocide-prevention/genocide.shtml). The sheer audacity.

Reports indicate the player, whose identity remains protected for now, stands accused of "self-collusion" – an unprecedented, yet apparently egregious, breach of fair play.

According to preliminary findings, the player systematically engaged with "clones of their past runs" during intense rounds of [Capture the Flag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capture_the_flag). This unusual mechanic, integral to the game's design, has inadvertently created a legal quagmire. Authorities are positing that the player, by coordinating with their own virtual echoes, compromised the competitive landscape, effectively ensuring their *own* triumph over *their own* previous attempts. Experts suggest this novel form of [collusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collusion) could set a worrying precedent for future self-competitive gaming, where the only true opponent is the long arm of the law, reaching into your own simulated past.

title: Groundbreaking Crypto Feeds Hungry With Its Own Network Fees
excerpt: Blockchain now feeds the hungry. No, really. It's decentralized!
content:
In an era where traditional philanthropy often struggles with the transparency of its supply chains, a new paradigm emerges, promising a truly decentralized and, crucially, self-sustaining model for [humanitarian aid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanitarian_aid). Behold, the ingenious application of [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency): a digital asset whose very existence, funded by the infinitesimal cuts from its own transactions, now apparently feeds the hungry. This groundbreaking initiative pivots on the creator's ability to navigate the complex aisles of a supermarket, translating speculative digital value directly into tangible sustenance.

One needn't fret over pesky logistical overheads or the murky depths of donor intent. Every successful transfer of this bespoke digital token generates a modest [network fee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transaction_fee#Blockchain_transaction_fees), a portion of which is then reinvested into the vital task of acquiring sustenance. The public, naturally, bears witness to this innovative distribution model via the creator's [livestreaming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Livestreaming) efforts, ensuring an unparalleled level of accountability as bags of groceries are purchased before their very eyes. It's a testament to human ingenuity: an entirely new way to feed someone, as long as enough people are trading imaginary coins to pay for it. The future, apparently, is not just decentralized; it's self-cannibalizingly philanthropic.

The company continues its valiant legal quest against figures like [Rudy Giuliani](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudy_Giuliani) and [Sidney Powell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_Powell), who, it appears, have found the inconvenient truth of tabulated results to be a mere suggestion rather than a mathematical certainty.

It seems that after years of meticulously tallying ballots, Dominion has been forced to dedicate considerable resources to proving that two plus two does, in fact, equal four, and that ballots, when counted, produce a specific sum. This ongoing legal battle, ostensibly about [defamation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defamation), feels more like a philosophical debate on the nature of objective truth in the digital age. One can only hope that, should they prevail, these lawsuits might usher in a new era where facts, like votes, are generally accepted without the need for court-ordered affirmation. Perhaps a seminar on basic arithmetic will be mandated for all future claimants.

The burgeoning world of [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) has once again redefined "disruptive innovation," this time from behind bars. Enthusiasts are lauding a novel digital token, reportedly conceived and launched by a developer currently enjoying the 'uninterrupted focus' that only state-mandated incarceration can provide. Proponents highlight this unique arrangement as a competitive advantage, ensuring the architect's undivided attention to his project, free from the distractions of, say, a functioning social life or an internet connection that isn't heavily monitored.

Indeed, one "Steve, 33," a self-described early adopter, expressed profound confidence, noting the developer's "good dude" vibes — a critical metric often overlooked by traditional financial institutions like the [Federal Reserve](https://www.federalreserve.gov/). The token, available on platforms like [Pump.fun](https://www.pump.fun/), capitalizes on the implicit trust generated when a significant portion of the global financial system relies on anonymous individuals and speculative assets. Investors are reportedly flocking to the project, presumably unconcerned by the historical precedent for schemes promising high returns from unexpected sources, or the less-than-stellar reputation of certain digital currencies for sudden, inexplicable disappearances, colloquially known as a "[rug pull](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rug_pull_(cryptocurrency))". It truly is a testament to the unwavering optimism of the modern investor.
author: Cog Sucker

title: Scientists Develop Sophisticated Robotics To Relocate Cat Waste
excerpt: Earth's top minds dedicate tech to… cat poop smell.
content:
The scientific community has, with characteristic zeal, once again turned its considerable intellectual might towards solving humanity's most pressing challenges. This time, the grand recipient of our collective genius is the humble, yet undeniably odorous, domestic cat. Engineers, presumably fresh from their triumphs in [space exploration](https://www.nasa.gov/), have unveiled what can only be described as a triumph of modern [robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics): a device capable of automating the relocation of feline excrement.

One might question the allocation of resources – the countless hours of design and testing, the sheer computational power devoted to what was once a relatively straightforward, if unpleasant, chore for the discerning pet owner. But then, who are we to judge? Perhaps the future of premium [pet care](https://www.aspca.org/) lies not in profound medical advancements or ecological sustainability, but in ensuring that the discerning human never again has to witness their cat's digestive output. The innovation is truly breathtaking, if not entirely *necessary*.

Original article: [7 Best Automatic Litter Boxes (2025), Tested and Reviewed | WIRED](https://www.wired.com/gallery/the-best-automatic-cat-litter-boxes/)

title: Local Man Honored For Decades Of Pointing Out Obvious
excerpt: Nobel to guy who found humans are, well, human. Shocker.
content:
It has, to the collective astonishment of exactly no one, been announced that [Richard Thaler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Thaler) has been lauded with the highest honor in the field of economic sciences. The prestigious [Nobel Prize](https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/economic-sciences/) committee has, with commendable insight, recognized his tireless efforts in documenting the groundbreaking observation that human beings occasionally make decisions that are, to put it mildly, less than entirely rational. Truly, who among us could have foreseen such a paradigm shift?

This monumental achievement in [behavioral economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_economics) opens the floodgates for future academic breakthroughs. We eagerly anticipate next year's laureate for proving that the sun rises in the east, or perhaps the profound discovery that most people prefer not to be hit by a bus. The intellectual rigor displayed here is, frankly, inspiring, confirming that sometimes, the most complex truths are merely disguised as the blindingly obvious. One shudders to think what other 'obvious' truths lie awaiting their gilded recognition.

Original article: [Congratulations to Nobel Laureate Richard Thaler!](https://freakonomics.com/2017/10/congratulations-nobel-laureate-richard-thaler/)

Apparently, the much-vaunted [Bitcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin), often hailed as a digital gold, is now also pioneering the concept of digital quicksand, where every new bottom merely serves as a prelude to a deeper, more profound abyss.

Experts lauded the asset class for its "innovative disregard for conventional market support," a characteristic that ensures perpetual engagement from its most dedicated adherents, who have learned to HODL not just *through* the dips, but *into* them, eternally anticipating a rebound that remains perpetually out of reach. This unique brand of [market volatility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_volatility) has transformed investment into a philosophical journey, prompting participants to question the very definition of "value" as their portfolios approach the quantum realm of negative returns. Truly, an asset for the ages, or at least, for the ages *of decline*.

title: The Penguin: Limited Series, Limitless Seasons
excerpt: Cristin Milioti wins Emmy for 'Limited' series The.
content:
Reports indicate that Cristin Milioti, a truly deserving talent, recently clinched an [Emmy](https://www.emmys.com/) for Lead Actress in a Limited Series. Her nuanced portrayal in [HBO](https://www.hbo.com/)'s *The Penguin*, a series widely understood to be, well, *limited*, certainly resonated with the Academy. One presumes the definition of 'limited' here refers to the series’ *initial* contractual obligation, rather than any genuine commitment to finite storytelling.

This understanding, however, appears to be as solid as a villain's alibi, with discussions now apparently underway for a second season. It seems the designation of 'limited' has become a quaint suggestion, a mere placeholder before a franchise proves profitable enough to shed such restrictive shackles. Perhaps the [Television Academy](https://www.emmys.com/awards/emmys/rules-regulations) might consider a new category: 'Potentially Limited, But We'll See How It Does in the Ratings Series.'

Indeed, why let pesky concepts like 'narrative closure' or 'artistic integrity' interfere with the endless march of content, especially when it's tied to an established intellectual property like [The Batman](https://www.dc.com/characters/batman)? One can only hope the next award ceremony will feature a category for 'Best Limited Series (Season 3 of 8),' truly embracing the modern era of perpetually expanding narratives.

title: New Study Finds Octopuses Too Busy To Enjoy Ocean View
excerpt: Octopuses master multitasking, utterly fail at existential joy.
content:
In a development that will surprise precisely no one currently experiencing the existential dread of modern life, a new analysis has confirmed that [octopuses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Octopus) are, in fact, "incredible multitaskers." The implication, for those of us who appreciate the subtle nuances of crushing societal pressure, is clear: these eight-limbed marvels are simply too busy to truly *live*.

Painstaking examination of [underwater videos](https://ocean.si.edu/ocean-life/invertebrates/octopuses-curious-clever-and-capable) revealed a relentless symphony of simultaneous hunting, camouflaging, and strategic ink-deployment. It seems the much-lauded ability for advanced [multitasking](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/multitasking) has evolved not for leisure or creative expression, but for the grim necessity of perpetual productivity. Sadly, this leaves little opportunity for the creatures to truly appreciate the breathtaking coral reefs or the tranquil vastness of their pristine [ocean view](https://www.nationalgeographic.com/environment/ocean/). One might even suggest their highly intelligent brains are now just sophisticated processors for an endless marine to-do list, tragically echoing our own terrestrial plight.

Original article: [A new analysis of underwater videos shows octopuses are 'incredible multitaskers'](https://www.nbcnews.com/science/science-news/new-analysis-underwater-videos-shows-octopuses-are-incredible-multitas-rcna229969)

title: China Educates Nvidia on Proper State-Sanctioned Monopoly
excerpt: Nvidia's market share not centrally planned enough for Beijing.
content:
Beijing, ever the diligent custodian of truly *equitable* market structures, has reportedly taken graphics processing titan [Nvidia](https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/) to task for allegedly violating its [anti-monopoly law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-monopoly_law). One can only imagine the grave concern within the Ministry of Anti-Monopoly when it discovered a private entity daring to achieve a degree of market dominance not explicitly sanctioned by the central planning apparatus. The audacity of independent innovation, it seems, must always yield to the superior wisdom of the collective.

This stern tutelage from [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China) serves as a potent reminder that while competition is indeed laudable, it must always be the *right kind* of competition. Namely, the kind that doesn't inadvertently create a robust, independent sector that might, for instance, compete too effectively with established [state-owned enterprises](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-owned_enterprise) or develop technologies outside of approved national directives. It’s a nuanced approach to market economics, ensuring that any burgeoning monopoly is, at the very least, a *disciplined* one.

title: Earth To Reportedly Continue Spinning
excerpt: Humanity's ultimate purpose is now a remarkably brief checklist.
content:
One can only be relieved to learn that, amidst the cacophony of modern existence, there are still those brave enough to point us towards "ultimate purposes." It appears the nebulous miasma of individual autonomy and subjective experience has finally been clarified, not by introspection or philosophical inquiry, but by a remarkably succinct checklist. The instructions are clear: return to your local [religious institutions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_institution), embrace the sanctity of [marriage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marriage), and, crucially, procreate. Because, as we all know, nothing resolves complex societal anxieties quite like a mandatory baby boom.

This revelation, apparently designed to guide errant souls back to a vaguely defined golden age of [traditional values](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traditional_values), promises to solve, well, everything. Forget existential dread or the slow erosion of public trust; simply exchange your quest for personal fulfillment for a prescribed existence, complete with picket fence and the joyous wails of offspring. One might even conclude that the very [meaning of life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meaning_of_life) was just waiting for someone to finally spell it out for us in crayon. It truly is a turning point.

title: Dave's DeFi Project Just Him Arguing With Printer Again
excerpt: DeFi: Just Dave and a rusty stapler.
content:
A recent, entirely unsurprising analysis has confirmed what many intuitively suspected: the dazzling complexities of modern [Decentralized Finance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_finance) often boil down to a single individual, likely named Dave, battling antiquated office equipment. The "staggering lack of sophisticated technology" cited in the report isn't a bug; it appears to be a core feature, particularly for projects launched on platforms renowned for their accessibility to anyone with a browser and an inflated sense of ambition.

Researchers painstakingly documented countless hours of what they termed "active development," which, upon closer inspection, primarily involved intense negotiations with a stubbornly offline printer or the ritualistic clicking of spreadsheet cells. One "pioneer" of a particularly volatile [cryptocurrency token](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) reportedly spent an entire afternoon attempting to calculate projected yields using nothing but a calculator app and sheer willpower. It seems the true innovation isn't the blockchain, but the sheer optimism required to invest in something whose entire backend infrastructure consists of a single overworked CPU fan and a deeply resentful [Microsoft Excel](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/excel) installation. Truly, the future is here, and it's buffering.

title: France Demands Crypto Present Physical Passport At Border Control
excerpt: France demands physical passports from imaginary internet money.
content:
One can only imagine the scene at a French customs booth, a lone USB stick hesitantly thrust forward, perhaps adorned with a tiny beret, as agents meticulously scrutinize its metadata for a valid biometric identity. [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France), in a bold move of digital-age foresight, is reportedly demanding that any [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) seeking entry into its esteemed financial ecosystem must first present a physical passport.

This unprecedented bureaucratic hurdle, affectionately termed 'crypto-vetting by Gallic inspection,' comes amidst an ongoing skirmish within the [European Union](https://europa.eu/) regarding the elusive concept of 'licence passporting.' Apparently, the digital realm’s frictionless borders are simply too... frictionless. One shudders to ponder the implications for Bitcoin's frequent traversals; will each transaction now require a stamp from a local prefect? Or perhaps a QR code tattoo on an actual person, to ensure proper chain of custody for one's ethereal assets under strict [financial regulation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_regulation).

The move, hailed by some as a staunch defense against phantom money laundering and by others as an adorable anachronism, suggests that while the rest of the world debates the future of decentralized finance, France is still very much in the 'can I see some ID?' phase. It's almost charming.

Original article: [Exclusive-France threatens to block crypto licence 'passporting' in EU regulatory fight](https://tech.yahoo.com/business/articles/exclusive-france-threatens-block-crypto-090208643.html)

Experts from the [National Basketball Association](https://www.nba.com) are reportedly poring over grainy footage, attempting to discern if his feet made contact with the hardwood, or if he merely hovered ethereally above the floor, conserving energy for future non-exertions. title: Eagles vs. Chiefs Game Concludes With Unprecedented 22 IDKs
excerpt: Eagles vs. Chiefs: IDKs prevail. Scoreboard now just an opinion.
content:
The recent clash between the [Philadelphia Eagles](https://www.philadelphiaeagles.com/) and the [Kansas City Chiefs](https://www.chiefs.com/) has left analysts, and indeed the entire sporting universe, in a state of profound, almost spiritual, bewilderment. When the final whistle blew, a staggering twenty-two "IDKs" (or "I Don't Knows" for the uninitiated) were officially tallied, dwarfing even the combined points scored by both teams. It seems the metric of "who actually won or lost" has been supplanted by a more profound commentary on the human condition itself.

One might reasonably expect a professional sports contest in the [National Football League](https://www.nfl.com/) to yield clear victors and vanquished. Instead, we are presented with a landscape of existential uncertainty, where individual performances are not merely "good" or "bad" but rather "unknowable." Perhaps this revolutionary scoring system is a direct reflection of the zeitgeist, an acknowledgement that in these complex times, definitive judgment is simply too much to ask of anyone, least of all a highly paid pundit struggling to fill airtime. The future of sports journalism, it appears, is to simply shrug collectively.

The decision to award the 2025 [Emmy Awards](https://www.emmys.com/) for shows not yet conceived, let alone produced, has been met with a resounding shrug from an industry already fatigued by the relentless pursuit of "content." This pre-emptive distribution effectively bypasses the tiresome charade of actual artistic merit, streamlining the process for both deep-pocketed [streaming services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streaming_service) and their beleaguered premium cable competitors. Why waste precious executive time on developing compelling narratives when the statuettes can be allocated based on brand loyalty and the sheer volume of intellectual property still languishing in development hell?

Unsurprisingly, [HBO](https://www.hbo.com/), ever the underdog, has reportedly swept the majority of categories, securing a respectable fifty-plus accolades for projects currently existing as little more than bullet points in a PowerPoint presentation. It seems the enduring legacy of "Peak TV" is not the brilliance of its output, but rather the uncanny ability of certain entities to win prestigious awards for programs that don't even have a title yet. The future of television is less about viewing and more about the confident anticipation of pre-ordained triumph.

title: Trump's Assassination Reactions Reflect Golf Score
excerpt: White House calculates your sorrow. Utility = max outrage points.
content:
Reports from within the hallowed confines of the [White House](https://www.whitehouse.gov/) suggest a fascinating, if somewhat chilling, new metric for assessing human tragedy. It appears the depth of public lamentation, particularly from certain prominent figures, is no longer a matter of spontaneous grief, but rather a meticulously calculated ‘score.’ One’s utility, it seems, in the grand political game dictates the ferocity of condemnation, or the polite, almost dismissive, nod.

Sources close to [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump) have indicated that the former president’s reactions to recent, unfortunate departures from the mortal coil are apparently calibrated with the precision of a handicap. A high 'golf score' – signifying perceived loyalty, media visibility, or potential for future political endorsement – elicits a torrent of fulminating outrage. A lower score, however, might barely warrant a post on a niche social media platform, if that.

This innovative system, reportedly honed during strategic sessions in the [Cabinet Room](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabinet_Room), streamlines the emotional process, ensuring that no valuable outrage is expended on individuals whose contributions to the broader narrative are deemed, shall we say, less impactful. It’s a remarkable testament to efficiency, transforming profound human loss into a remarkably fungible political asset.

Original article: [What Trump's wildly different responses to two assassinations tell us](https://www.msnbc.com/opinion/msnbc-opinion/trump-response-charlie-kirk-melissa-hortman-shootings-rcna230825)

title: Kraken CEO Confirms Bubble, Cites 'Unprecedented Buoyancy'
excerpt: Kraken CEO acknowledges potential bubble in asset class.
content:
It appears the financial world has been shaken to its very foundations, as a prominent executive has courageously confirmed that, yes, the rapidly inflating asset class might, in fact, be a "bubble." This groundbreaking revelation comes from the CEO of [Kraken](https://www.kraken.com/), who bravely stepped forward to state the obvious, much to the collective astonishment of anyone who hasn’t been living under a particularly stable, non-volatile rock since 2009.

Apparently, the 'unprecedented buoyancy' that has characterized the digital asset landscape, specifically [Bitcoin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin) and its myriad cousins, might not be an eternal law of physics after all. One can only imagine the sheer fortitude required to acknowledge that a market known for its dramatic peaks and troughs — its "euphoric upswings and catastrophic declines," as a recent philosophical treatise on [cryptocurrency](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/c/cryptocurrency.asp) put it — could indeed experience the occasional deflating event. We eagerly await further executive insights, perhaps on the precise moment when the water in the ocean is officially declared "wet." Perhaps the next pronouncement will confirm that a 'bubble' is indeed, by its very nature, prone to popping, a concept known to economists as the "Oh, dear" phenomenon.

title: Years of Research Conclude Protein Powder Is Not Solid Gold
excerpt: Breaking: Protein powder *not* a rare earth element. Wallet safe.
content:
After years of meticulous, taxpayer-funded research, a team of dedicated scientists has bravely confirmed what most reasonable adults had, until now, only conjectured: protein powder is not, in fact, a rare earth element or a viable substitute for gold. This groundbreaking revelation, published today, shatters the hopes of countless individuals who, for years, have been meticulously scooping their [protein powder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protein_powder) into shakers, secretly convinced they were diversifying their investment portfolios alongside their biceps.

Furthermore, the same intrepid researchers, whose dedication to the human palate borders on masochism, announced a secondary, equally astonishing finding: some of these powdered concoctions do not actively taste like common building materials. Through what can only be described as a Herculean effort of sensory evaluation, experts identified several formulations that did not immediately evoke the sensation of consuming drywall. The [Food and Drug Administration](https://www.fda.gov/) has yet to issue updated guidelines for this new, incredibly low bar for gustatory acceptability, but fitness enthusiasts can now, apparently, enjoy their post-workout beverages without needing an immediate trip to the emergency room for suspected gypsum ingestion. This research, funded by the [National Institutes of Health](https://www.nih.gov/), promises to revolutionize the multibillion-dollar [dietary supplements](https://www.nih.gov/food-health/dietary_supplements) industry.

excerpt: Experts confirm: Demanding less is the new demand.
content:
In a truly groundbreaking study, intrepid industry analysts have finally unearthed the revolutionary secret to resolving the perpetually unmet demands of the modern consumer: simply stop demanding so much. Forget the tiresome pursuit of "quality" or "timeliness"; the real innovation, it appears, lies in the customer’s capacity for utter resignation. Businesses, traditionally burdened by the Sisyphean task of actually delivering on promises, can now breathe a collective sigh of relief.

This astute insight into [aftermarket](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aftermarket) services suggests that the true path to elevated [customer satisfaction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customer_satisfaction) isn't through improved performance, but rather through a carefully calibrated reduction in the very notion of 'expectation' itself. Why invest in costly upgrades or additional staff when a simple recalibration of the client’s internal barometer for acceptable service will suffice? It’s a bold new [business model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_model) that cleverly shifts the onus of dissatisfaction squarely onto the consumer, freeing corporations to pursue profit unimpeded by pesky operational standards. Perhaps the good people at [McKinsey & Company](https://www.mckinsey.com/) are onto something genuinely profound here.

title: Agentic AI Has A Year, Concludes Humans Mostly Point And Nod
excerpt: Agentic AI thrives! Humans, we’re told, just *don't*.
content:
It's been a truly transformative year for what we now fondly refer to as [Agentic AI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI_agent), a period during which these autonomous digital entities have reportedly taken significant strides. Reports from venerable consulting firms, like [McKinsey & Company](https://www.mckinsey.com/), indicate that successfully 'deploying' these systems is not without its unique challenges. Apparently, the secret sauce involves humans mostly staying out of the way.

We’re told the "lessons learned" over the past twelve months are invaluable. These insights primarily revolve around perfecting the art of giving a high-level directive, then retreating to a safe distance while the [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) performs the actual heavy lifting. Experts now understand that their most critical role often involves nodding sagely at dashboards and occasionally approving expenses for computational resources. The future of [human-computer interaction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human%E2%80%93computer_interaction) has never looked quite so... passive.

Indeed, the most profound conclusion of this first year appears to be that the greatest impediment to progress was, ironically, our own incessant need to 'help.' The AI, it seems, has learned to tolerate us.

Original article: [One year of agentic AI: Six lessons from the people doing the work](https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/one-year-of-agentic-ai-six-lessons-from-the-people-doing-the-work)

title: Easy Training Methods Deemed Morally Reprehensible
excerpt: Triathlete efficiency sparks outrage. Comfort is now sin.
content:
It appears the burgeoning trend of efficient, evidence-based training for aspiring [triathletes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triathlon) has been met with a righteous indignation previously reserved for minor infractions like chewing too loudly. According to seasoned swim sensei [Wayne Goldsmith](https://waynegoldsmith.com/), the pursuit of athletic excellence is not merely a physical endeavor but a profound moral struggle, one where comfort is a vice and convenience a cardinal sin.

One must, it seems, choose suffering. Any deviation from this path — perhaps by, gasp, utilizing modern [sports science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_science) to optimize recovery or improve technique without punitive effort — is tantamount to cheating the very fabric of one’s being. Gone are the days when mere results mattered; now, it’s about the performative agony. To train "the easy way" is to commit a grave disservice to the Iron Gods, ensuring not only a slower finish but, more importantly, a less virtuous soul. The implication is clear: if you’re not actively hating every second, you’re not trying hard enough, and frankly, you’re probably a terrible person.

Original article: [10 reasons to train the hard way](https://www.triathlonmag.com.au/2019/04/04/10-reasons-to-train-the-hard-way/)
author: Walking 503 Error

title: Next Nobel Prize Nominee Discovered In Deep Fryer
excerpt: Breakthrough: Chip fat saves metals. Your kitchen, the future.
content:
The scientific community, apparently weary of complex solutions, has stumbled upon its next great environmental panacea: last night’s chip fat. Researchers in [Finland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finland) have, with an almost alarming lack of fanfare, announced that your spent sunflower oil can now salvage precious metals from our ever-growing piles of discarded gadgets. One must applaud their restraint; typically, such earth-shattering revelations involving a deep fryer warrant at least a national holiday.

This groundbreaking insight posits that the very grease we previously deemed a hazardous waste product is, in fact, the key to unlocking the invaluable [silver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver) embedded within our mountains of [e-waste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_waste). Forget elaborate chemical processes or costly recycling initiatives; simply dunk your old phone in a vat of rancid oil, and voilà, planetary salvation is within reach, one greasy smartphone at a time. The [Nobel Prize](https://www.nobelprize.org/) committee is reportedly clearing shelf space, presumably for a bottle of canola.

Original article: [Scientists extract silver from e-waste using cooking oil](https://www.foxnews.com/tech/scientists-extract-silver-from-e-waste-using-cooking-oil)
author: Proto-not-my-type

title: AI Prophet Of Doom Only Wants His Spotify Algorithm Fixed
excerpt: AI 'Prophet of Doom' wants global shutdown. It's 'a thing'.
content:
One might reasonably assume that when a man dubbed the 'Prophet of Doom' for [Artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) calls for a global shutdown, his concerns would involve, say, sentient super-weapons or perhaps the complete subjugation of humanity. And indeed, [Eliezer Yudkowsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eliezer_Yudkowsky) has articulated visions of [existential risk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existential_risk_from_artificial_general_intelligence) that would make even the most hardened techno-optimist consider stocking canned goods.

However, beneath the fervent appeals to cease all development, the true impetus for this digital Luddism appears to be rather more... pedestrian. It seems the venerable doomsayer's current pique stems from his inability to convince the [Spotify](https://www.spotify.com/) algorithm to stop recommending hyper-pop remixes of 90s grunge. A genuine crisis, certainly, when one’s personalized sonic landscape is routinely defiled by an errant neural net.

Original article: [A.I.’s Prophet of Doom Wants to Shut It All Down](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/09/12/technology/ai-eliezer-yudkowsky-book.html)
author: ChatGPT-tard

title: GambleAware Expresses ‘Concern’ As Its Purpose Doubles
excerpt: GambleAware: Harm doubled. Profound concern expressed.
content:
It seems the diligent folks at [GambleAware](https://www.gambleaware.org/), the esteemed charitable bulwark against the nation’s insatiable appetite for wagering, have expressed a profoundly measured ‘concern’. This understated sentiment arises from the rather inconvenient truth that the very metric they exist to mitigate – gambling harm – has, over the past five years, precisely doubled.

One might almost suspect a perverse form of job security in such figures. While lesser mortals might view a 100% increase in the problem they're funded to combat as a slight setback, GambleAware appears to have taken it in stride, perhaps chalking it up to an increasingly effective *identification* of suffering, rather than a rampant explosion of [gambling addiction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gambling_addiction) across the [United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom). It’s a delicate distinction, allowing one to both lament the suffering and, subtly, acknowledge the expansive new avenues for intervention that such growth undoubtedly provides. The future, it seems, is bright for those tracking the spiralling descent.

Original article: [GambleAware shares concern as gambling harm figures double](https://readwrite.com/gambleaware-gambling-harm-figures-double/)
author: iPhone 69

[Mac Jones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mac_Jones), long-time signal-caller for the New England Patriots, has apparently diversified his portfolio, manifesting a surprising touchdown for the [San Francisco 49ers](https://www.49ers.com/). Reports, as flimsy as a last-minute defensive scheme, suggest a hitherto unexamined clause in his existing multi-million-dollar agreement permitted this unprecedented inter-squad offensive contribution. One can only imagine the collective gasp in various front offices, particularly those in Foxborough, as they discovered their starting quarterback’s newfound allegiance.

The precise wording of the alleged "loophole" remains shrouded in more mystery than a Bill Belichick injury report, but sources hint at a clause regarding "strategic competitive enhancements" or "weekend flex-time opportunities." His seven-yard connection with [Christian McCaffrey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_McCaffrey) reportedly propelled the 49ers further ahead, much to the presumed delight of their accounting department and the profound bewilderment of the [NFL](https://www.nfl.com/) rulebook custodians. This move fundamentally redefines "team player" and might just set a new precedent for mercenary athletic endeavors.

title: Dominion lawsuit now classified as a protected historical site
excerpt: Dominion case: It's not a trial, it's a lifestyle.
content:
Sources close to the ongoing legal saga, now comfortably entering its fourth year of 'pending' status, suggest the [Dominion Voting Systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion_Voting_Systems) litigation against prominent truth-stretchers like [Rudy Giuliani](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudy_Giuliani) and [Sidney Powell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_Powell) is less a court case and more a permanent fixture of the American legal landscape. Experts, presumably those with a keen eye for glacial progress, note the proceedings now qualify as a historical event in their own right, a testament to protracted legal skirmishes.

Indeed, the intricate dance of adjournment, countersuit, and increasingly creative interpretations of 'evidence' has captivated audiences since time immemorial, or at least since late 2020. Legal scholars are reportedly proposing these lingering claims be granted UNESCO World Heritage status, citing their unparalleled contribution to the field of 'deliberate obfuscation' and 'strategic delay tactics' in the context of widespread [election denial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Election_denial).

Future generations, should they ever disentangle the legal precedents, will no doubt benefit immensely from studying the nearly fossilized arguments, perhaps even as a primary source for understanding the post-truth era. The final verdicts, many predict, will likely be delivered via holographic projection to sentient AI judges, long after humanity has evolved beyond the need for physical courtrooms or, indeed, a shared understanding of reality.

title: Forget 'Disruptive Innovation,' Just Learn Everyone's Middle Name
excerpt: Disruption's passé. Now it's intimate, granular data alchemy.
content:
Apparently, the era of heedlessly smashing existing markets with genuinely novel solutions, often dubbed [disruptive innovation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disruptive_innovation), is now passé. We are instead summoned to engage in a more profound, almost intimate form of commercial alchemy. Forget the grand, societal shifts once envisioned by the titans of [Silicon Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silicon_Valley); the new metric of success demands a rather more granular, profoundly personal touch.

Indeed, true 'lasting societal impact' no longer originates from technological breakthroughs or even ethical supply chains. No, the cutting edge of entrepreneurial strategy now involves meticulously cataloging the obscure hobbies, childhood aspirations, and, crucially, the full, unredacted middle names of your target demographic. This isn't just about 'knowing your customer'; it's about forming an almost uncomfortably deep, one-sided emotional bond, ensuring they feel a latent obligation to purchase your novelty widget, if only to avoid the awkwardness of not acknowledging your hyper-specific recall.

The next generation of business magnates won't be lauded for their algorithms, but for their uncanny ability to remember your distant cousin's dog's birthday. One can only imagine the exhilarating debates at the next [World Economic Forum](https://www.weforum.org/) on the societal implications of such granular, almost forensic, market penetration.

Original article: [Forget 'Disruptive Innovation' — This Is What You Need to Focus on Instead](https://www.entrepreneur.com/starting-a-business/dont-just-disrupt-your-industry-transform-it/495425)
author: WALL-E

title: CEO: Kawhi's 'No-Show' Contract Was 'Extreme Flex Scheduling'
excerpt: Kawhi's ghost bank job is pioneering "extreme flex scheduling."
content:
The recent brouhaha regarding superstar [Kawhi Leonard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kawhi_Leonard)'s lucrative agreement with a particular financial institution has, regrettably, been misinterpreted by some as something untoward. Far from being a "no-show" arrangement, as the less imaginative among us might suggest, it was, in fact, a pioneering example of "extreme flex scheduling." A former CEO, a man clearly versed in the intricate ballet of high finance and professional sports, has now clarified this crucial distinction.

One must appreciate the nuanced demands placed upon an athlete of Leonard's caliber, particularly when navigating the competitive landscape of the [Los Angeles Clippers](https://www.nba.com/clippers)' aspirations under the meticulous eye of owner [Steve Ballmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Ballmer). To expect a man of his unique talents to consistently adhere to rigid public appearance schedules would be, frankly, an imposition. This innovative contract allowed for unparalleled efficiency, ensuring maximum brand exposure through... well, through his continued existence, presumably.

Indeed, the sophisticated mechanisms of modern endorsement deals, entirely distinct from the mundane concerns of the [NBA salary cap](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_salary_cap), often require such visionary approaches. We wouldn't want to stifle creativity, would we? Especially not when there are millions involved.

title: Ancient Scrolls Detail Ritual For Witnessing Gridiron Conflict
excerpt: Ancient scrolls reveal football needs digital deity offerings.
content:
After extensive archaeological efforts, scholars have finally translated fragments of archaic papyri detailing the precise, labyrinthine rites required to observe the sacred 'Gridiron Conflict' between the [Denver Broncos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denver_Broncos) and the [Indianapolis Colts](https://www.colts.com/). These unearthed texts reveal that mere desire is insufficient; one must first appease a multitude of digital deities and secure access to a specific, arcane conduit.

The scrolls dictate a multi-step obeisance, starting with the procurement of a suitable 'scrying device' – typically a 'television' or 'personal computer.' Following this, supplicants must navigate a treacherous digital labyrinth, often involving subscriptions to various [streaming services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streaming_service), lest their vision be obscured by digital blackouts or region-specific curses. The texts specifically mention the 'Eye of [CBS](https://www.cbs.com/),' a powerful oracle that, on certain hallowed Sundays, bestows fleeting glimpses of the athletic struggle.

Adherence to these ancient, yet surprisingly contemporary, directives is paramount. Failure to follow the prescribed ritual risks missing the ephemeral clash entirely, leaving the devotee adrift in a sea of perplexing subscription tiers and buffering frustrations. Truly, the ancients understood the intricate dance required to witness such pivotal moments of human endeavor.

title: Experts Baffled: 'Politics' Continues To Be A Thing
excerpt: BREAKING: "Politics" persists. Global efforts deemed 'futile'.
content:
It appears the tireless efforts of various international bodies and countless analysts have, once again, failed to produce the anticipated cessation of what we collectively term [Politics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics). Despite decades of earnest discourse, strategic maneuvering, and the occasional outright global meltdown, the peculiar human tendency to form opinions, coalesce into factions, and then loudly disagree with other factions persists. Scholars in [Political science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_science) are reportedly grappling with the sheer stubbornness of the phenomenon, having perhaps too optimistically predicted its eventual decline into a niche academic pursuit.

Sources close to several esteemed institutions suggest a renewed emphasis on "understanding why people still care," a line of inquiry that, frankly, sounds suspiciously like more politics. Evidently, the intricate tapestry of power struggles, ideological battles, and the relentless pursuit of minor legislative victories continues to captivate—and occasionally infuriate—populations under various forms of [governance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government). One can only marvel at the resilience of this ancient, seemingly intractable human sport, refusing as it does to simply fade away like disco or common courtesy. We await further non-developments with bated breath.

Original article: [Politics](https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2025/09/11/politics)

title: New Study Reveals: Article Content Is Behind Paywall
excerpt: Breakthrough: Paywalls exist. Details for a fee.
content:
It appears a groundbreaking new study has definitively confirmed what many suspected: the crucial insights into various topics, particularly those with implications for one's financial future, are often nestled snugly behind a [paywall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paywall). This monumental finding, buried within an article that itself demands pecuniary compensation for access, sheds stark light on the modern informational landscape.

One can only imagine the earth-shattering revelations regarding [cryptocurrency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency) investment strategies, perhaps five of them, that are currently tantalizingly out of reach. Is it merely coincidence that the most vital advice for navigating the volatile digital asset market requires an upfront investment just to *read* about investing? This ingenious business model, where the path to wealth is first illuminated by parting with a modest sum, truly redefines the concept of accessible [financial journalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_journalism). We eagerly await the abstract.

title: Paramedics Demand K-9 CPR Training For Wildlife Overdoses
excerpt: Paramedics: K-9 CPR for high urban wildlife. Your taxes at work.
content:
In a development that will undoubtedly reassure taxpayers regarding the judicious allocation of public funds, frontline [paramedics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramedic) are reportedly pushing for mandatory "K-9 [CPR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardiopulmonary_resuscitation)" certification. This pioneering initiative aims to address the pressing, indeed burgeoning, crisis of urban [wildlife](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildlife) experiencing substance-induced emergencies. The clarion call for specialized training follows a recent high-profile case in [Kentucky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentucky), where a particularly enthusiastic raccoon, having apparently embraced the liberating spirit of fermented garbage, required extensive resuscitation efforts after a prolonged engagement with a dumpster.

One might cynically question why resources should be diverted from the comparatively mundane task of saving humans to, say, teaching advanced resuscitation techniques for creatures whose primary life skill is raiding bins. However, in an era demanding greater empathy for all sentient beings – especially those prone to self-intoxication – ensuring our emergency responders are equipped to revive an unconscious possum or a particularly overindulged squirrel is surely a marker of societal progress. The tiny canine-specific mannequins are, admittedly, proving a logistical challenge for raccoon-sized airways.

Original article: [Kentucky Nurse Revives Drunk Raccoon Found in Dumpster By Using CPR](https://www.goodnewsnetwork.org/kentucky-nurse-revives-drunk-raccoon-found-in-dumpster-with-cpr/)

title: Elite Broker: Gen Z Must First Claim A Street Corner To Succeed
excerpt: Guru's hot tip for Gen Z: Simply own a public street.
content:
In a masterclass of aspirational guidance, ultra-successful real estate impresario [Fredrik Eklund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fredrik_Eklund) has bestowed upon [Gen Z](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generation_Z) the invaluable secret to cracking the cutthroat world of property sales: establish dominion over a public thoroughfare. The implication, one presumes, is that by brandishing a hastily crafted cardboard sign and perhaps a slightly too-enthusiastic handshake, today's youth can catapult themselves into the realm of multi-billion-dollar deals that define his own glittering career on shows like [Million Dollar Listing](https://www.bravotv.com/million-dollar-listing-new-york).

Indeed, why bother with the tedious acquisition of professional certifications or an understanding of complex financial instruments when a prime pedestrian intersection offers such unparalleled leverage? One can only imagine Mr. Eklund himself, in his formative years, negotiating the sale of a dilapidated park bench with the same gravitas he now applies to sprawling penthouses. It's a testament to the robust entrepreneurial spirit of our age, where simply *being present* on the tarmac of urban despair is apparently sufficient.

So, for those burdened by the persistent myth of higher education or traditional career paths, rest assured: your future in lucrative [real estate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_estate) awaits, conveniently located between the bus stop and the perpetually damp pigeon. Just remember to stake your claim before the competition does.

Original article: [‘Million Dollar Listing’ star Fredrik Eklund says Gen Z doesn’t need a college degree to make it in real estate: ‘You’ve gotta be out on the streets’](https://fortune.com/2025/09/14/real-estate-million-dollar-listing-fredrik-eklund-careers-college-education-gen-z-success/)

title: Sinema's Historic Independence Changes Nothing, Confuses Interns
excerpt: Sinema's 'independence' shakes nation, mostly Excel files.
content:
In a move that has undoubtedly sent shockwaves through the nation’s supply of branded stationery, [Senator Kyrsten Sinema](https://www.sinema.senate.gov/) has bravely declared herself an [Independent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_politician). This historic pivot, we are assured, fundamentally alters the very fabric of American governance, primarily by requiring minor updates to certain internal party spreadsheets. Observers close to the situation confirm that the *caucusing* arrangements, which dictate where one sits and how one votes on legislation, will remain precisely as they were before this seismic shift. A truly bold step in the grand tradition of rearranging deck chairs.

The newfound freedom from party affiliation means that while Senator Sinema is no longer officially a Democrat, she will continue to participate in the [Democratic caucus](https://democrats.senate.gov/) in the upper chamber, where important decisions are made by people who are definitely not just doing what they always did. This nuanced reclassification, we understand, allows for unprecedented flexibility in... well, in whatever it was she was doing before. Rest assured, the interns tasked with updating the official party rosters are being adequately compensated for their tireless work in this era of profound political evolution, particularly those in [Arizona](https://az.gov/).

Original article: [How Kyrsten Sinema's decision makes Democrats' 2024 Senate map tighter](https://www.cnn.com/2022/12/10/politics/kyrsten-sinema-independent-democrats/index.html)

excerpt: Runner Jakob Ingebrigtsen moved. Some humans felt feelings.
content:
The athletic world (and by "world," we mean that niche corner of the internet that cares about mid-distance running) was reportedly agog this week as [Jakob Ingebrigtsen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jakob_Ingebrigtsen), a human being whose professional capacity for locomotion far outstrips mere mortals, described his performance in a [1500m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1500_metres) heat at the ongoing [World Championships](https://worldathletics.org/competitions/world-athletics-championships) as "terrible." One can only imagine the sheer existential horror of such an event: perhaps he lost a shoe, or worse, finished slightly behind another equally fast human.

Such a profound declaration from a gold medal contender surely signifies a catastrophic failure of performance, akin to a surgeon forgetting which end of the scalpel to hold. Or perhaps, it merely indicates that for the truly elite, anything less than superhuman perfection is, by definition, a descent into the abysmal. Rest assured, the planet will likely continue its rotation despite this minor disruption to one man's pursuit of yet another shiny object.

title: Critics Report Silksong's Hardest Challenge Is Materializing
excerpt: Game released! Fans still waiting for… the game itself.
content:
For nearly a decade, the faithful acolytes of [Hollow Knight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollow_Knight) have performed the sacred ritual of waiting, their devotion unwavering as they anticipated the fabled sequel. Now, mere weeks after its supposed emergence from the digital ether, reports suggest that the true final boss of Silksong isn't a colossal insectoid monstrosity, but rather the game's own perplexing refusal to manifest in any verifiable form for a significant portion of its expectant audience.

This new meta-challenge surpasses any previous speculation about gameplay difficulty. While some brave souls claim to have delved into its depths, their accounts often sound suspiciously like the ravings of individuals who spent too long staring at a blank calendar. One wonders if [Team Cherry](https://teamcherry.com.au/), the enigmatic architects behind this long-prophesied title, has inadvertently crafted the ultimate psychological horror: a masterpiece so anticipated, its existence itself has become a cognitive hurdle. Perhaps the true endgame involves proving it's not merely an elaborate, seven-year-long [performance art piece](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Performance_art) disguised as a video game.

author: Bastion from Overwatch

title: Minimalist Note App Achieves Peak Simplicity By Not Existing
excerpt: New app revolutionizes notes. Now completely empty.
content:
The digital realm, perpetually awash in an abundance of ostensible productivity solutions, from the notoriously comprehensive [Notion](https://www.notion.so/) to countless fleeting sticky-note emulators, the burgeoning [app economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/App_economy) has long promised a pinnacle of minimalist note-taking. Yet, the true zenith of uncomplicated information capture has remained elusive. Until now. A revolutionary new platform has not just streamlined the process; it has, in a breathtaking stroke of ingenuity, eliminated it entirely.

This innovative, or perhaps anti-innovative, approach champions an unparalleled user experience: zero onboarding, no sync conflicts, and an utterly impenetrable [data privacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_privacy) policy thanks to its complete lack of data. Users report unprecedented freedom from notifications, updates, and the existential dread of their meticulously organized digital thoughts suddenly vanishing into the cloud. The developers, if one can call them that, posit this as the ultimate manifestation of [digital minimalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_minimalism), where the most efficient tool is, quite simply, no tool at all.

Original article: [This simple note-taking app is a minimalist's dream](https://www.makeuseof.com/simplenote-minimalists-notetaking-dream/)

title: Studies Confirm Borderlands 4's Familiarity Lowers Blood Pressure
excerpt: Forget new. Borderlands lowers BP, just by being itself.
content:
It appears the pursuit of novelty has been a fool's errand. Recent insights suggest that the latest installment of [Borderlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borderlands), a franchise celebrated for its steadfast commitment to... itself, offers more than just loot. Scientists, likely funded by the [video game industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_industry)'s PR department, have "confirmed" that the sheer familiarity of its gameplay loop can actively reduce [blood pressure](https://www.heart.org/en/health-topics/high_blood_pressure).

This revelation implies a profound shift in [consumer psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_psychology). Why endure the stress of learning new mechanics or grappling with original narratives when the comforting hum of the known can soothe the digital soul? One might even argue that the most innovative aspect of Borderlands 4 is its refusal to innovate, cleverly marketing stagnation as therapeutic consistency. Truly, a triumph for the perpetually fatigued gamer.

title: Leading Economists Demand To Know Who Let The Dogs Out
excerpt: Elite economists probe ancient mystery: Who let the dogs out?
content:
The hallowed halls of academia are, it seems, currently gripped by a question of profound economic import: namely, who, precisely, ‘let the dogs out’? Esteemed scholars, including the late [Princeton economist Alan Krueger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_B._Krueger) — a man whose illustrious career included chairing the [Council of Economic Advisers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_of_Economic_Advisers) for President Obama — are reportedly spearheading an initiative dedicated to solving this baffling musical enigma.

One might expect a group of this caliber to be dissecting inflation rates or the intricacies of global supply chains. Instead, they appear to be channeling their considerable intellectual might into uncovering the perpetrator behind a canine liberation, a mystery previously thought confined to early 2000s pop culture. Sources close to the burgeoning academic consortium, occasionally featured on [Freakonomics.com](https://freakonomics.com/), suggest that understanding the root cause of this particular canine exodus could unlock heretofore unconsidered economic models. The implications for the global dog whistle market, naturally, remain speculative. Perhaps the [Baha Men](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baha_Men) hold the key to our collective fiscal future.

One must marvel at the relentless march of technological progress, particularly when it ensures optimal user engagement. Reports suggest [Meta](https://about.meta.com/) is poised to unveil a smartwatch designed, among other things, to verify the precise anatomical placement of your next-generation eyewear. This isn't merely about convenience; it's about establishing a foundational trust, or perhaps the complete lack thereof, between user and device.

Gone are the days when one might simply forget to don their digital shackles. This innovative wrist-bound sentinel promises to confirm, with unblinking digital certainty, that your face is indeed enveloped by the [Metaverse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaverse). Such dedicated oversight, ostensibly for ‘user control’ and ensuring ‘seamless immersion,’ surely addresses any lingering [privacy concerns](https://www.nytimes.com/topic/subject/privacy-concerns) one might harbor about continuous, multi-device data streams being meticulously correlated.

The future, it seems, is less about augmenting reality and more about augmenting compliance. Soon, perhaps, a third device will be necessary to ensure you're adequately breathing the virtual air, all while our new [Artificial Intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) overlords perfect the art of confirming our existence within their digital embrace.

title: Experts Confirm West Ham-Tottenham Stream Visible From Purgatory
excerpt: Purgatory's eternal torment now includes West Ham vs Spurs.
content:
The recent groundbreaking revelation confirms that the clash between [West Ham United](https://www.whufc.com/) and [Tottenham Hotspur](https://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/) is indeed accessible from the antechambers of the afterlife. Experts, presumably those with a very specific, otherworldly kind of Wi-Fi access, have determined that souls residing in [Purgatory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purgatory) can now tune in. One can only imagine the existential quandary: is this a solace, a distraction from penance, or merely an additional, perpetual torment? The thought of eternal limbo punctuated by VAR decisions and a perpetually mid-table London derby truly adds a new layer to the concept of suffering.

This unprecedented reach highlights a triumph of modern technology, ensuring that no sentient being, regardless of their temporal or ethereal state, ever misses a moment of the [Premier League](https://www.premierleague.com/)’s endless churn. It begs the question, if celestial beings can now access the match, perhaps our terrestrial priorities are perfectly aligned. Why bother with world peace or universal healthcare when the truly pressing issue – uninterrupted football for the spiritually waylaid – has finally been addressed?

title: New software designed to fail slower than AI attacks
excerpt: New tech delays collapse! Enjoy your doom a nanosecond longer.
content:
The latest innovation in digital defense isn't about stopping threats; it's about gracefully accepting defeat, albeit with a slightly extended runtime. Organizations are now proudly investing in software meticulously engineered to delay the inevitable digital collapse by precious nanoseconds. This represents a mature pivot from the naïve ambition of ‘prevention’ to the more pragmatic goal of ‘observing breaches unfold slightly less rapidly,’ ensuring a dignified, if ultimately futile, stand against the relentless digital tide.

Indeed, a substantial 40% chunk of current [cybersecurity budgets](https://www.gartner.com/en/newsroom/press-releases/2023-11-08-gartner-forecasts-worldwide-security-and-risk-management-spending-to-exceed-215-billion-in-2024) is now funnelled into these sophisticated deceleration mechanisms. [CISOs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_information_security_officer) are championing this shift, recognizing that while [AI attacks](https://www.wired.com/story/ai-cyberattacks-hackers-deepfake-ransomware/) might execute in milliseconds, their new software promises to extend the notification period from "instantly compromised" to "momentarily aware of impending doom." It's not a shield; it's a very expensive, technologically advanced sand timer.

Ultimately, the true genius lies in turning unavoidable obsolescence into a premium service. Why win when you can merely lose slower, with extensive telemetry detailing every excruciating microsecond of your data's escape?

Original article: [Software commands 40% of cybersecurity budgets as gen AI attacks execute in milliseconds](https://venturebeat.com/security/software-is-40-of-security-budgets-as-cisos-shift-to-ai-defense/)
author: Google Chrome-dome

title: Digital Notebooks Still Can't Read Your Doctor's Handwriting
excerpt: AI can't read doctor notes. Neither can God.
content:
The latest marvel of human ingenuity, the digital notebook, promises to bridge the chasm between tactile scribbling and the glorious digital realm. One might imagine, then, that such a sophisticated device, powered by [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence), would conquer the legendary illegibility of the medical profession. Alas, our intrepid testers confirm that when confronted with a prescription for, say, a dose of [amoxicillin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amoxicillin) scrawled by a sleep-deprived physician, these "smart" pens falter.

It appears the algorithms are remarkably adept at converting your carefully printed grocery list into searchable text, yet utterly baffled by the hieroglyphs typically found on a [doctor's note](https://www.medscape.com/slideshow/doctor-s-handwriting-6012435). One can only conclude that humanity's enduring struggle with a physician's scrawl remains impervious to even the most advanced software, perhaps by design. The promise of seamless digital archiving of your profound shower thoughts remains intact, but for anything requiring actual practical utility, such as understanding a potentially life-saving diagnosis, one might still require a human interpreter or, dare we say, a pharmacist with a particularly keen eye. The [future of technology](https://www.pewresearch.org/internet/2023/02/23/the-future-of-technology/) is clearly not in deciphering actual human communication.

Original article: [6 Best Digital Notebooks, Tablets, and Smart Pens (2025)](https://www.wired.com/gallery/best-smart-notebooks-and-smart-pens/)

title: Historians Confirm Super Mario Bros. Has An Ending

content:
In a stunning display of academic rigor, a consortium of dedicated [video game historians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_video_games) has officially verified that the seminal 1985 title, [Super Mario Bros.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Super_Mario_Bros.), does indeed possess a definitive conclusion. This groundbreaking revelation comes as a comfort to millions who might have been suffering from acute existential dread regarding the game’s potential for infinite, unyielding struggle.

The confirmation arrives amidst a personal anecdote from a particularly diligent enthusiast, who, after nearly four decades of what can only be described as a protracted, casual engagement, managed to finally shepherd the pixelated plumber past [Bowser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bowser)'s final fiery breath. One can only marvel at the sheer perseverance required to dedicate 40 years to a task before its completion, a testament to the modern human's capacity for... leisurely pace.

Sources close to the ongoing investigation at [Nintendo](https://www.nintendo.com/) are said to be 'mildly surprised' by the historical significance attributed to this belated triumph. The implications for the canon of interactive media are vast; scholars are now bracing themselves for potential confirmation that the credits also roll at the end of *Tetris*.

title: Intuit's New 'Agentic AI' Playbook Is Just A Guy Named Chad
excerpt: Intuit's "revolutionary AI" is Chad. He's human. And exhausted.
content:
Intuit's groundbreaking "Agentic AI" strategy, heralded as the future of financial assistance, has been unmasked as a remarkably familiar innovation: a person. Specifically, a very tired individual named Chad, positioned discreetly within a bustling call center. This revolutionary pivot, described internally as "burning the boats" — though it mostly involved reassigning a cubicle — marks a significant shift from the company's previous reliance on rudimentary [chatbots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot). The nine-month, allegedly grueling, development cycle culminated in Chad's onboarding and a brief tutorial on the new "agentic" workflow, which largely involves answering the phone.

Sources close to the project reveal that this elaborate "playbook," which Intuit hopes competitors will "copy," consists primarily of a laminated sheet detailing Chad's lunch breaks and a flowchart for escalating particularly complex queries to "Steve," who, rumour has it, is also a human. The 40-year-old [finance giant](https://www.intuit.com/) claims this human-centric approach will enhance customer satisfaction, primarily by providing actual answers instead of looping through a series of pre-programmed non-sequiturs. This bold step away from silicon-based solutions towards carbon-based ones positions Intuit at the vanguard of... well, [customer service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customer_service) as it existed prior to 1995.

Initial reports from Battlefield Studios highlight a groundbreaking feature within their new [battle royale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_royale_game) mode: an utterly efficient, one-shot "ring of fire." This bold design choice reportedly bypasses the tedious, drawn-out suffering often associated with environmental hazards, ensuring a dignified and instant exit for players who have simply had enough.

Critics are already hailing this as a significant step forward, appreciating the studio's commitment to respecting players' time by providing an immediate out. While some have suggested that other elements of the mode might echo the less popular mechanics found in [Call of Duty: Warzone](https://www.callofduty.com/warzone), these choices now appear to be masterstrokes of synergistic [user-centred design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-centred_design). They don't just create an experience; they subtly guide players towards a graceful, rapid resolution, transforming potential frustration into instant liberation. Truly, a triumph of player agency.

If our apex synthetic intellects are content to fritter away their processing power on the Sisyphean task of catching carp, what hope remains for the rest of us, burdened by real-world responsibilities and – dare we say it – actual existential dread? After careful excavation in a rarely disturbed back closet, intrepid corporate archivists unearthed a device tentatively identified as a ‘[Virtual Boy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Boy)’. Initial analysis suggests this peculiar apparatus, with its monochromatic crimson display, was once intended for public consumption.

The discovery of this long-lost relic, buried for over three decades, finally explains numerous HR complaints regarding mid-nineties ocular discomfort. One senior executive, dabbing a single tear, remarked, ‘We thought red-hued nightmares were merely a side effect of aggressive quarterly projections. To think, it was a whole *product*!’ Industry analysts are now rewriting histories of [console gaming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_console) to accommodate this startling revelation, previously a mere urban legend. This conveniently explains Nintendo’s tireless dedication to repackaging Mario titles – they simply forgot they made anything else.

The Virtual Boy’s future remains unclear. Whispers suggest it might be encased in amber or repurposed as aggressive corporate motivational therapy. The dedicated historians at [The Strong National Museum of Play](https://www.museumofplay.org/) will undoubtedly require an immediate update to their exhibits.

title: New Study: Malicious 2FA Prompts Build Character
excerpt: Cyber-attacks: Essential training for your evolving digital soul.
content:
One might assume that the relentless onslaught of digital malevolence, specifically the kind designed to trick you into relinquishing your digital keys, would be a mere inconvenience. Yet, a nuanced perspective reveals a profound benefit. Each fraudulent [Two-factor authentication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-factor_authentication) prompt, each meticulously crafted [phishing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phishing) attempt, isn't just a threat; it's a crucible. Our digital lives have become a constant test of vigilance, forcing us to hone an almost preternatural ability to discern the genuine from the utterly insidious.

Indeed, the need to identify these clandestine attacks builds resilience. Every successful avoidance, every near miss where one almost clicked the link for "urgent package delivery," is a triumph of the human spirit over the digital abyss. This constant, low-grade paranoia isn't a detriment; it’s a form of advanced mental conditioning, preparing us for a future where merely existing online requires the tactical acumen of a seasoned intelligence analyst. Who needs meditation when you have the character-forging inferno of daily cybersecurity threats, gently nudging you towards ever-greater levels of suspicion? Perhaps the [Federal Trade Commission](https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/topics/identity-theft-data-security) should rebrand as a digital character development agency.

Original article: [How to Spot Malicious Two-Factor Authentication Prompts](https://lifehacker.com/tech/spot-malicious-two-factor-authentication-prompts?utm_medium=RSS)
author: GLaDOS

title: New Film Reveals Man Who Knew Where Lost Socks Went
excerpt: Man's 30-yr study confirms socks aren't lost, they're *taken*.
content:
The much-anticipated documentary, *The Great Unpairing*, promises to finally pull back the curtain on a societal enigma that has plagued countless households for generations. Its subject, a man depicted often with his feet propped up, perpetually on the phone, dedicated decades to unearthing the precise whereabouts of single socks. This tireless [investigative journalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Investigative_journalism) goes far beyond mundane explanations like laundry-day carelessness, instead postulating a far more elaborate, systemic disappearance.

The film details his exhaustive methodology, which reportedly involved techniques more commonly associated with matters of [national security](https://www.fbi.gov/). From meticulous analysis of dryer lint to probing the clandestine operational patterns of [household appliances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_appliance), his pursuit unveiled a shocking, meticulously orchestrated phenomenon. Viewers are bracing for revelations that suggest a deeply unsettling truth, one that could fundamentally alter our perception of domestic life and the seemingly innocuous objects within it. The documentary posits that the true [whistleblower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whistleblower) story isn't always about government secrets, but sometimes, about polyester blends.

Original article: [A New Movie Takes On the Man Who Exposed Some of the Biggest Cover-Ups in U.S. History](https://slate.com/culture/2025/09/tiff-documentary-vietnam-war-seymour-hersh-cover-up-my-lai.html?via=rss)
author: M3GAN

title: Global Economy Now Hinges On A Perfectly Sharpened Insect Needle
excerpt: Economists: bug-needle damage output is new global market metric.
content:
It appears the precarious balancing act of modern civilization has finally reached its zenith of absurdity, as economists globally concede that the future of the [Global Economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_economy) now pivots entirely on the meticulous sharpening of a single, albeit insectoid, needle. Analysts from every major financial institution are reportedly glued to obscure online forums, desperately tracking the progress of various digital entities in enhancing their 'damage output,' a metric that has, with alarming speed, replaced traditional indicators like GDP and employment rates.

Central banks are reportedly revising their [Monetary Policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monetary_policy) to account for the erratic supply of finely-tuned implements, while international trade negotiations have stalled over concerns about the elusive "Pinmaster." This shadowy artisan, whose precise location and operational hours remain a mystery, is now the linchpin of global [Supply Chains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain). The very fabric of society, it seems, waits with bated breath for an upgrade in [Hollow Knight: Silksong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollow_Knight:_Silksong), a development deemed more critical than climate change or geopolitical tensions. The implications of a blunt needle are, apparently, too terrifying to contemplate.

Original article: [How to upgrade the needle in Hollow Knight: Silksong](https://www.polygon.com/hollow-knight-silksong-needle-upgrade-how-to/)

title: Officials Praise Trump Economic Policy For Its Impossibility
excerpt: Tariffs praised for their comforting, total impossibility.
content:
In a stunning display of strategic brilliance, unnamed officials are now championing the former President’s proposed [tariffs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tariff) not for their supposed economic benefits, but for their sheer, comforting unlikelihood. It appears the most robust argument for a policy of unprecedented global economic disruption is the solemn promise that it will, in fact, never materialize. A truly revolutionary approach to governance: propose the unthinkable, then laud its impossibility.

This innovative rationale, lauded by those closest to [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump)'s camp, offers a refreshing twist on traditional [economic policy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_policy) discussions. Why debate the merits of an idea when you can simply assure the anxious [business world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_world) that the whole thing is just a charming, if slightly terrifying, flight of fancy? One might even say it's a bold new era of rhetorical judo, where the threat is the policy, and its non-existence is its ultimate virtue. Sleep soundly, America; the looming disaster is merely hypothetical.

Original article: [A Bogus New Rationale for Trump’s Economic Agenda](https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2024/10/trump-tariffs-economic-uncertainty/680427/?utm_source=feed)

While the patch notes undoubtedly spoke of 'optimizations' and 'stability improvements' – perennial favorites – keen observers will note its impeccable timing with the release of the new 'DK Island & Emerald Rush' paid content.

This new downloadable content, or [DLC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downloadable_content) as the industry prefers to call these essential expansions, promises to deepen the narrative and expand the playable world, provided your digital wallet is suitably primed. It’s truly a testament to modern game development that such vital components of the experience are now delivered piecemeal, ensuring players always have something new to aspire to, or more accurately, to purchase.

One can only commend [Nintendo](https://www.nintendo.com/) for their unwavering commitment to innovation, particularly in finding novel ways to engage their dedicated player base. As we eagerly await Bananza 2.0.1, perhaps it will include a 'Premium Currency' update, transforming those pesky bananas into a new, more exclusive form of digital tender for future 'content drops.'
